characters: SIR RICHARD POLE, THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD
IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE
THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SCREEN
BACK TO YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD
THROUGH THE CRACKS OF THE STAGE'S FLOORBOARDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sidewalks are filled with theater-goers heading for their shows. Cabs line the streets.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE ALLEY
dialogues.text: A cab quickly turns into the alley, coming to a screeching halt. A Man in a Grey Suit jumps out and rushes to the side entrance of a theater. In the background we see that the title of the play, "Anonymous", is written on the theatre's marquee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the Man in the Grey Suit as he rushes through narrow backstage hallways, passing several ACTORS dressing in Elizabethan costumes, applying their make- up, etc... TITLES CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are still closed, and the sound of the audience excitedly MURMURING behind them is heard. . Stagehands are moving stage lights as--

dialogues.speaker: A STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: takes a nervous peek through the curtains to check the audience-- it's a full house. He holds a prop umbrella in one hand, anxiously checks his watch in the other. He looks on both wings of the stage-- and then relief floods his face as he sees The Man in the Grey Suit hurrying over to him. The Stage Manager wordlessly hands him the umbrella and signals to a stagehand in the background. The curtains start to OPEN and the MURMUR of the audience dies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the umbrella stands on the empty stage, a single light on him. He is "PROLOGUE". (We will see the same actor later as the "Prologue" of Henry V). "Prologue" regards his audience for a   beat before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soul of the Age! The applause, delight, the wonder of our stage! Our Shakespeare, rise... (beat, repeating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Shakespeare... For he is all of ours, is he not? The most performed playwright of all time! The author of 37 plays, 154 sonnets, and several epic poems that are collectively known as the ultimate expressions of humanity in the English language. And yet... And yet... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a single manuscript of any kind has ever been found written in Shakespeare's own hand. In four hundred years, not one document-- be it poem, play, diary or even a simple letter. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was born the son of a glove-maker, and at some unknown time, armed with but an elementary school education, he went to London where, the story goes, he became an actor and eventually a playwright.

dialogues.speaker: OFF STAGE
dialogues.text: A stagehand takes a wooden hammer and beats against a flat metal pate, creating the SOUNDS of THUNDER. Another stagehand starts to lift shutters in front of a stage light back and forth to create LIGHTNING STRIKES.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "Prologue" opens his umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died at the age of 56, and was survived by his wife and two daughters who were, like Shakespeare's own father, irrefutably illiterate.

dialogues.speaker: OFF STAGE
dialogues.text: In the rafters a stagehand opens valves.   It starts to RAIN. PROLOGUE (O.C.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His will famously left his second best bed to his widow. But it made no mention of a single book or manuscript. The actor who will play "Ben JONSON" (mid 30's) appears in the wings, bearded, ready to go on stage, holding a prop leather manuscript. Behind him a group of Elizabethan "soldiers" strap on their swords.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "Prologue" continues, as do TITLES. PROLOGUE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible Shakespeare owned no books at his death because... he could not read? That he wrote no letters because he, like his father before him and his children after him, could not write? (lets that sink in, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Shakespeare is a cypher, a ghost; his biography made not by history... but by conjecture. His story not written with facts, but with... imagination. The rain has intensified. "Prologue" turns and the camera starts to leave him and the TITLES END.... PROLOGUE (CONT'D) (more energetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! Let me offer you a different story. A darker story... Of quills and swords. Of power and betrayal. Of a stage conquered, and a throne lost! A FLASH OF LIGHTNING, and for a moment only sheets of RAIN are visible. No stage, no "Prologue". Then, trough the rain, we see a form of a man... Ben Jonson... running. Then we make out the shapes of houses... a street. We're not on a stage anymore. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson-- carrying the manuscript-- runs up the street toward a large circular theater. He frantically opens the wooden door to the theater--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and he quickly bolts it behind him, turns, and desperately looks for a place to hide. He runs towards the stage as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a dozen uniformed guards reach the door. They are led by Sir Richard POLE (40), Captain of the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it down! And several of the guards charge the door with their pikes, HITTING it hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson hurries backstage, and disappears from our view just as--

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. THE ROSE THEATER
dialogues.text: --the guards SMASH the door open.    Pole is the first in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson!   Jonson!!    Show yourself! The soldiers immediately spread out into different parts of the theater. Jonson's gone. Because--

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: has moved under the stage silently scurrying like a rat trying to find a place to hide among the stacks of props and costumes (swords, masks, flags and banners, shields, barrels, canons, etc.) But Jonson freezes when he sees--

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CRACKS OF THE STAGE'S FLOORBOARDS
dialogues.text: --the soldiers jump onto the stage and spread out, Pole amongst them. POLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out with you! Jonson! We'll smoke you out like a rat if we have to! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson?! Jonson!! Nothing.    A beat, then-- POLE (CONT'D) (to a soldier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torch it. The soldier hesitates. POLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torch it!   All of you! The soldiers obey, lighting fire to the walls, the galleries, the columns as--

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: GASPS in horror. Desperate-- he spies an open metal box nearby filled with un-used fireworks. He tosses the fireworks out of the box-- and then places the bound manuscripts in their place, then closes the box. Then-- he grabs a nearby rapier as--

dialogues.speaker: FLAMES
dialogues.text: --begin to take hold everywhere: the columns at the front of the stage... the trompe-l'oeil walls... the seating galleries... the columns...

dialogues.speaker: A TRAP DOOR
dialogues.text: opens center-stage, and Jonson JUMPS out, the rapier in his right hand, ready for a fight. But-- three soldiers jump onto the stage, pikes ready. Jonson-- no fool- turns and runs for the other end of the stage-- but then runs smack into four other soldiers! Ballocks! Jonson turns this way and that-- nowhere to run-- grins wryly, drops his sword. Raises his hands in surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson, his hands tied behind him, is pushed through the door, Pole following. A small crowd of actors, whores, etc., watch the theater burn. The guards have to push their way through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire reaches the fireworks below the theater's stage, and--

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: -- the SOUND of fireworks EXPLODING makes Jonson turn and see:

dialogues.speaker: THE THEATER
dialogues.text: Timbers CRASH and fireworks EXPLODE over the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A longboat carrying Jonson, Pole and the guards makes its way towards the Tower Of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is thrown into a chair, a guard on either side of him. It's dark-- the only light coming from a few torches in the walls, and a large fire pit at the far side of the room. An INTERROGATOR (30's) faces him.   Dressed all in black, he is wispy thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are Benjamin Jonson, playwright? Son of William Jonson, glass-blower, son of James Jonson brick-layer? Jonson nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have you ever been arrested before, Mr. Jonson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a writer, aren't I?   Of course I've bloody well been-- And a guard BACKHANDS Jonson on the face full force-- hard enough to send Jonson and the chair to the ground. His nose starts to bleed. As the Guards pull him up, the Interrogator looks across the room-- there is someone else there, a FIGURE, watching, but cloaked in the darkness. Jonson notices the figure as well.      We hear a voice from the darkness. FIGURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him about the plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Interrogator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plays? (to the Figure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which would you prefer, my lord? A pastoral? An historical? An historical-pastoral, or an hysterical historical pastoral-- And SMACK!    He's hit by the guards again.   He SPITS ou a tooth. INTERROGATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not interested in your plays, Jonson. We are interested in the plays given to you by Edward de Vere, Earl of Oxford. Jonson stares at him a beat, and then looks into the darkness. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry my lord, but I am not sure I know whereof you speak. I have had the honor of meeting his lordship-- And SMACK--

dialogues.speaker: FACES
dialogues.text: laughing. Not in this room, somewhere else. Somewhere outside. Before we really understand what we are seeing we are:

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE CELL
dialogues.text: Jonson blinks, trying to stay conscious.      His mouth i ripped, bleeding. So is his nose. The skin has broken on his forehead.     The Interrogator leans into the bloody Jonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the plays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Jonson even has a chance to answer-- SMACK!

dialogues.speaker: MORE FACES
dialogues.text: Laughing.    We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is nine years earlier. The faces come from an audience watching a play. They find the performance hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rose towers above the nearby buildings "Bankside" (the part of London that houses the theaters, whorehouses, etc.). The Rose towers above the nearby buildings "Bankside" (the part of London that houses the theaters, whorehouses, etc.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: TWO MEN
dialogues.text: walk towards the theater. Edward de Vere (47), the Earl of OXFORD, an intensely handsome man. His clothes have seen better days. His companion is Henry Wriothesley, Earl of SOUTHAMPTON (22). Blonde, attractive, a bit of a pretty boy-- and extremely enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning slightly) Well, it's certainly... big. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you, Edward, you've seen nothing like it before! Nothing! OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bricklayers and whores watching Aristophones?   You're quite right, Henry, not only have I never witnessed it, I'm not sure I care to. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing) You're an elitist, you know that, Edward? Oxford pauses at the entrance. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be puppets, will there? Southampton grins and gives a few coins to an USHER, who escorts the two of them (the retainers stay outside) inside. USHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lords...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usher takes them up a flight of stairs.    Oxford observes everything as they walk. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage-craft is quite spectacular. Far more elaborate than anything I've seen at court. I've witnessed be- headings that god as my witness look as real as at the Tower, cannons fired in battle... They come to the second floor, where a SELLING-MAID has a box of food and drink in front of her bosom-- much like a match-stick girl. SELLING-MAID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale?   Mutton, mi' lord? Southampton waves her off as they follow the usher up another flight of stairs. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and last week, they had some sort of a device to hoist cherubs into the air and fly over the entire audience! OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An apГІ mekhanes theГіs. Deus ex machina. Machine of the Gods. And as they ascend up more stairs, Oxford catches glimpses of the stage and performance through the rafters and over the heads of the attending audience. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever the Greeks wrote their heroes into a situation from which they couldn't write their way out-- Oxford is becoming intrigued by the theater, almost despite himself. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Out came the apГІ mekhanes theГіs... As when Hippolytus is saved by Artemis, or Medea flown to Athens... Always good for an apГІ mekhanes theГіs was Euripides Oxford continues up, two steps behind Southampton. They come to the third floor and enter the box seating area reserved for nobles, giving Oxford his first real look at the theater itself. Oxford looks around and sees-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience members LAUGHING-- others DRINKING-- maids SELLING food-- the actors ACTING... It's alive.   Magical.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO OXFORD
dialogues.text: Oxford takes it all in, almost stunned by it.

dialogues.speaker: ON-STAGE
dialogues.text: The actor William SHAKESPEARE (30) plays a commoner. He is handsome, sexy, charismatic; and holds a tankard of ale, and SWIGS from it constantly. Another actor SPENCER (30) plays "FASTIDIOUS"; a pompous, over-dressed, caricature of a nobleman. He wears an enormous feather on his hat. Also on stage is an actor called John HEMINGE (late 40's), who plays "Sogliardo" SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whither were you riding now, signior? "FASTIDIOUS"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, I? What a silly jest's that! Whither should I ride but to the court? SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O, pardon me, sir, twenty places more; your hot-house, your pig-house, or your whore-house! The audience ROARS in laughter as Shakespeare looks below at a buxom young lady among the "groundlings". He smiles seductively. She smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Jonson (now 25 and clean-shaven) is watching the performance from behind a curtain, silently speaking the lines with the actors.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RAISED SEATING
dialogues.text: A group of playwrights and poets watch the play with an air of judgement. They are: Christopher "Kit" MARLOWE (32), young, brilliant, a bit foppish (he likes the boys), Thomas NASHE (late 30's)-- a heavy-set, a hard drinking satirist-- and Thomas DEKKER (29), considered a bit of a hack by his colleagues. They are called the "Mermaid's Wits" because they frequent a pub named The Mermaid's Tavern. NASHE (takes a swig of ale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His second play, and almost a full house. (burps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a wit, does Jonson. MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might be so, but like a grain of wheat hid in a bushel of chaff: you shall seek all day ere you find it, and when you have it, it's not worth the search! The others smile as a WOMAN passes. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale!   Ale!! DEKKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe-- spot me a few pence, will you? Henslowe still owes me for "Shoemaker's Holiday". MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (retrieving coins) That would be because no one saw "Shoemaker's Holiday". DEKKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale here! Marlowe gives the woman a few pennies as-- NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kit... Isn't that one of your unrequited loves in the box over there? Marlowe glances across the theater and spots Southampton siting next to Oxford. MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns) But with whom? Tell me not he prefers the company of such old grey men as that! Nashe squints. NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think-- yes, by the beard, that's the Earl of Oxford. Old Tom Hooker used to play for him. Had his own acting troupe for private Court performances and the like. DEKKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if he needs any material? MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not any of yours. NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no-- that was years ago. Had a falling out with the Queen, I heard. He's more of a recluse than a patron these days.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare points to "Fastidious". SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, he, the noble there? Why, he's a gull, a fool, no salt in him i' the earth; man, he looks like a fresh salmon kept in a tub! Shakespeare struts around as though he owned the place. The more he talks, the more the audience ROARS in laughter. SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sleeps with a musk-cat every night, and walks all day hang'd in perfumed chains for penance. A GROUNDLING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi!   So that's what I been smelling! More groundlings laugh.     Interestingly--

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMEN
dialogues.text: in the box seats do not.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare continues his rant, speaking directly to the groundlings. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his skin tann'd in civet, to make his complexion strong, and the sweetness of his youth lasting in the sense of his sweet lady. And, sadly, the poor man's brain is lighter than his feather... As the audience HOWLS in laughter, we see:

dialogues.speaker: A NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: with a feathered hat gets up in fury, and exits the theater, his lady with him. The Audience LAUGHS at him as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare smiles triumphantly. SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a good and empty puff, but he loves you well, signior. I wish you well with him.

dialogues.speaker: OXFORD
dialogues.text: Watches the nobleman with the big feathered hat pass by.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Later in the play... Shakespeare returns backstage and takes a deep swig from his tankard. He's actually drunk, though his performance didn't show it at all. He spots Jonson, and grabs him. SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson! Wonderful dialogue! Wonderful. I hope your next-- HENSLOWE (O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will!   Will Shakespeare! Shakespeare turns to see a furious Philip HENSLOWE (50'S) heading his way. HENSLOWE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not ale in that goblet is it? Shakespeare hides the goblet behind his back. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale? Me? Drink during a performance? I am a professional sir! (burps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A complete and-- He is interrupted by SCREAMS.    Not from actors on stage, but by the audience.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE THEATER
dialogues.text: Complete panic erupts as dozens of The Queen's Guard STORM into the theater. Everyone tries to get out as quickly as possible, including the other actors, Henry CONDELL (20's), Thomas POPE (30's), William SLY (13).

dialogues.speaker: SIR RICHARD POLE, THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD
dialogues.text: --jumps on stage. POLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This play has been declared seditious and illegal by Lord William Cecil! The audience begins to BOO at the mention of Cecil. POLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are herewith ordered to disperse immediately! A GROUNDLING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you disperse William Cecil's arse! POLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest that man!

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it all.    Well! Off to Essex's then? He gets up. Oxford does not, seemingly interested in the real drama below as everyone hurries from the theater. SOUTHAMPTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward? Oxford turns to him, distracted, and nods.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Jonson pushes his way on stage. JONSON (to Pole)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seditious? Seditious?! It's a comedy for god's sake! There's nothing seditious about-- POLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi, is that right, is it?    And you know this because? JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I wrote the bloody thing!      And-
POLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest him as well! Jonson is grabbed by guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is THROWN into the cell, the door SLAMMED behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pox on you! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your carbuncled father! Jonson looks around-- the cell is filled with a dozen or so other prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People taxed to the point of starvation, Spain running the New World, open revolt in Ireland, Catholic plots everywhere you turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, Earl of ESSEX (28), is playing tennis against Southampton. He's handsome, red-headed, and, we will learn, very ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and how do the Cecils spend their time and energy? Shutting a theater! A theater, for god's sake? It's madness! No wonder the mob hates them so! The court is inside, and slightly different from today's game: the back walls are playable, somewhat like racquet-ball. Oxford sits on a bench, watching.   Essex SLAMS a shot, but it goes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! Essex looks furious, but holds his tongue.   Southampton prepares to serve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Southampton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, how many people were at that play? Southampton pauses before serving. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? I'm not sure, two thousand, maybe more. Southampton SERVES.   Essex returns, and another heated rally begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how many performances are there of a play like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five or six I suppose. He HITS the ball again, and this time Essex misses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Essex)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! Ten thousand souls. All listening to the writings of one man-- the ideas of one man. That's power, Robert. And if there is one thing the Cecils understand, it's power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when did words ever win a kingdom? I think I'll keep my sword, thank you very much. Southampton SERVES as Oxford smiles at Essex's naivetГ©.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southampton and Essex are dressing out of their tennis clothes and into their normal clothes, assisted by two valets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the valets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us. (they exit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry... Some of my men have... intercepted... some of William Cecil's recent correspondence with King James of Scotland... Southampton pauses in clothing himself.   This is serious. ESSEX (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil's all but promising him the throne... SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To James?   Elizabeth would never agree to- ESSEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is old. Ill. Not of her old mind. Sometimes she doesn't even recognize me. And yet, still she refuses to name an heir. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a Scotsman? On the Tudor throne? ESSEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not in the Privy Council. Elizabeth does everything the Cecils wish of her. Everything!

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM
dialogues.text: Oxford enters. They don't notice, though. He instantly realizes he shouldn't say anything. He listens as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESSEX (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think, Henry, if James owes Cecil his throne, Cecil will have more influence in the next reign than he does in this one. And after William Cecil, his hunch-backed son will take his place... (careful) That is why we must do everything in our power to ensure that the right man succeeds her. (beat) A man deserving of the Tudor crown. Southampton stiffens at that last phrase. ESSEX (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask you for the support of you and your men, Henry.... if it comes to a fight. Southampton looks at Essex hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you need not ask. I stand with you, as I always have. Essex smiles at him warmly. They both HEAR something shuffle behind them. They turn, and see:

dialogues.speaker: WHERE OXFORD WAS STANDING
dialogues.text: Nothing.   He is gone.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SOUTHAMPTON AND ESSEX
dialogues.text: They exchange a slightly worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later, Oxford and Southampton are exiting the elaborate building that serves as Essex's London residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex played rather poorly, didn't he? Southampton just nods, distracted.   Oxford reaches out to him, and touches his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry... The Cecils brook no rivals. Southampton pauses, confused for an instant, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: his discussion with Essex)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard? Oxford nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always concerned for me, aren't you Edward? They keep walking towards Southampton's men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would you have me do? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have you deny him. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The son of the Queen? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is rumor only, Henry-- They stop. Southampton makes sure that his men are out of earshot. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumor? My god, all you have to do is look at Essex to see the Queen's reflection. Everyone thinks he's her son, everyone! And I for one would rather bow to a Tudor, bastard though he may be, than a Scotsman! OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I desire nothing more than to see the next king be the rightful king. But what Essex contemplates will surely lead to Civil War. (beat) No. If this is to be done, it must be done carefully, skillfully. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I heard it, Elizabeth exiled you from her presence for the last twenty years because of your "skill" at Court politics. And then he feels instantly ashamed of having said that. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only have your interests in mind, Henry. For as you so rightly point out, my interests are already lost. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Forgive me. You know how I feel about you. You have been a great friend to me ever since my father died. I promise you that I will do nothing rash without consulting you first. Oxford nods, still worried, and Southampton heads for his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry! Will you do me one thing more? Deliver a gift for me? A rather... elaborate gift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stone house is nothing like a stereotypical Tudor house; it's enormous, and very ornate and intricate in design. It faces the river, and has an elaborate docking area which is now filled with all sorts of longboats letting the noblemen off for a week-end get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of England's nobility is assembled in small groups, talking. It's a dour, quiet affair. Some music, no life. Quite Puritan. Southampton is there, but Essex and Oxford are nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: A HUNCH-BACKED MAN
dialogues.text: --makes his way through the room, causing conversations to cease as he walks by. Even the most senior of the nobles bow their heads slightly in greeting him. This is Sir ROBERT CECIL (mid 30's). He pauses near Southampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord of Southampton. (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Essex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he is still in the viewing chamber with her majesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp, annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone? SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) With your father in London dealing with all the troubles in Ireland, who else should the Queen turn to but Essex? Robert Cecil looks annoyed, but holds his tongue as the SOUND of pikes HITTING the floor silences the hall. A FOOTMAN clears his throat and-- FOOTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the grace of god, her majesty, Elizabeth, Queen of England, Wales and Ireland!

dialogues.speaker: DOUBLE DOORS
dialogues.text: open, and Elizabeth (in her 60's) enters. She is wearing a large sparkling pearl-encrusted dress with a wide collar. She walks slowly and carefully, and has a slight tremor in her head and hands. She seems un-certain; like she's not sure she recognizes all the faces around her (Alzheimer's?). And she compensates for it by being all the more regal, all the more un-human. Essex is on her arm, dressed in a splendid jewel- encrusted doublet. Robert Cecil FROWNS at the sight of Essex on her arm. Essex ignores Cecil's glare, notices Southampton-- ESSEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Ah-- Majesty, I've been told my lord of Southampton has a gift for you. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes sparkle) A gift? SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, your grace, though not from me. Southampton CLAPS his hands and a door across the room OPENS. A DWARF enters, followed by dancing faires, actors swirling sparklers, and musicians playing music. Elizabeth's rheumy eyes widen in complete delight, a smile of total jubilation crosses her face. Robert Cecil, on the other hand, looks horrified. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you this gift, my precious little man? DWARF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, my most majestic majesty. I am a free man. My gift is a play, majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A play? The dwarf bows his assent. ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Dwarf) Plays are the work of the devil, born from a cesspool of plague, whoredom, thievery, fornication, and heresy. You may tell your master that her majesty-- ESSEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) --Will gladly accept your gift. Robert Cecil turns to Essex, shocked. ESSEX (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Of course that is if you so desire, majesty. (to Robert Cecil) The choice is her majesty's to make, not yours. Is that not so Sir Robert? Robert frowns as Elizabeth looks around, unsure of the political tides around her. Then-- ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the dwarf) Comedy? Or tragedy? DWARF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comedy, majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) A comedy! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By... Anonymous, your majesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anonymous...? (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I do so admire his verse... Elizabeth lets go of Essex, and offers her hand to the Dwarf, who smiles brightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead us to this gift. And the Dwarf leads Elizabeth towards the door. Essex follows, and Southampton locks into step next to him. They exchange a knowing look as-- Robert Cecil steps in line far after the Queen, not happy with this turn of events as we hear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless thee, Bottom! Bless thee!      Thou art translated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheer magic. Candles everywhere: in stakes, in the ground, in the trees. They light a make-shift "stage" surrounded by huge oak trees on three sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me; to fright me, if they could. But I will not stir from this place, do what they can. Chairs have been brought out and put in rows in the grass. Elizabeth is watching center front row (of course). She loves it, SQUEALING in delight like a young woman. Essex is next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Several actors are mid-scene in "A Midsummer Night's Dream" (Act 3, Scene 1), their make-up quite elaborate and fantastical: "Bottom", who is costumed as a man-- except that he has a DONKEY'S HEAD, "Quince", a commoner, "Puck", played by the dwarf who is now dressed like a cupid, and "Titania", Queen of the fairies, who is presently asleep in a bed of fur. Puck hides behind a tree watching. "BOTTOM" (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will walk up and down here, and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Oxford watches from behind a curtain, carefully observing the Queen's reaction. Somehow we feel that seeing her again after so many years stirs up some deep emotion in him.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "BOTTOM" (CONT'D) (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ousel cock so black of hue, With orange-tawny bill, The throstle with his note so true, The wren with little quill-- Titania awakens in her nest-like bed of fur. "TITANIA"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What angel wakes me from my flow'ry bed?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: strongly reacts to Titania awakening.   It stirs some memory in her. A pleasant memory.

dialogues.speaker: OXFORD
dialogues.text: watches, delighted by her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Elizabeth watching. But it is an Elizabeth only 26 years old (referred to as YOUNG ELIZABETH in this script). We HEAR the sound of other dialogue, but from the same play. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight years earlier. And YOUNG ELIZABETH watches an earlier, slightly less sophisticated staging of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" (the costumes and sets are a bit more thrown together). All the actors are children from 7-12 years old or so.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: A boy watches in the exact same position as we just saw Oxford. This is BOY OXFORD-- now only 10 years old. But he is made up and wears a winged costume for the character of "Puck".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the owner of it blest ever shall in safety rest. Trip away; make no stay; meet me all by break of day. And the characters of "Oberon" and "Titania" exit.     Bo Oxford hurries--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we shadows have offended, think but this, and all is mended, that you have but slumber'd here while these visions did appear... Next to Young Elizabeth, JOHN DE VERE, Oxford's father, also watches, his face beaming with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And this weak and idle theme, No more yielding but a dream, gentles, do not reprehend; if you pardon, we will mend.

dialogues.speaker: A STERN LOOKING MAN
dialogues.text: is watching a few seats   away from Young Elizabeth.   He is WILLIAM CECIL (40's,   Robert's father). He is a Puritan, dressed all in   black (with a white lace collar), and has a long   beard. He is frowning, loathing the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, good night unto you all. Give me your hands, if we be friends, and Robin shall restore amends. The play now over, Young Elizabeth applauds with delight, as do the small group of courtiers all around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely.    Lovely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A make-shift "back-stage" where all the young "actors" are removing their costumes and make-up, including Boy Oxford, who sits in front of a make-shift, leaning mirror. Much excited talking and commotion, until Boy Oxford notices everyone has gone silent. He turns-- his winged costume still on-- just as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!    There he is. Young Elizabeth and her senior Court, including William Cecil and John De Vere, have entered. Boy Oxford bows deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Boy Oxford)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father tells me you wrote this evening's play yourself. Boy Oxford glances at his father-- should he answer directly? His father NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did indeed, your majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sport with me. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compose something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Now. BOY OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what subject, your grace? She thinks.   Then-- YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Truth... BOY OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks, then--) For... Truth... is Truth... Though... never so old... and time cannot make that false, which once was true. She smiles, claps. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John de Vere) My lord of Oxford. It seems you have added a poet to your family's long line of warriors. BOY OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, I am as accomplished with the sword and the musket as I am with verse. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Are you indeed? BOY OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods seriously) It is my only desire to one day be your majesty's most trusted servant in matters both of war and state, if you will but have me. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmed) Why, Lord Cecil, it seems we may very well have found your replacement. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hope not too soon, majesty, we hope not too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how liked you our young lord's play, William? William Cecil stiffens in discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Boy Oxford, conspiratorially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Lord Cecil is our most religious of subjects, and no doubt thinks your little masque will deliver your soul straight into the arms of Lucifer himself. Don't you, William? The Boy Oxford looks at William Cecil, perplexed by such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is God's decision, your majesty. Not mine. William Cecil looks directly at John de Vere resulting in an uncomfortable silence. Elizabeth notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if plays are indeed such a sin, I pray I do not find my salvation until very late in life. Boy Oxford smiles.   He might very well be in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight years later. The door SWEEPS open and a snoring, sleeping Jonson is awakened by--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson!    Ben Jonson! The other prisoners make way as the guard approaches Jonson. The guard tosses a wax-sealed piece of parchment onto Jonson's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been released. Jonson looks at it, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got powerful friends, now, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is in a nobleman's longboat (for the first time in his life). Across from him sits FRANCESCO-- Italian, 60's-- wearing a doublet with the Oxford coat of arms on its chest. The City of London is far in the distance. Jonson looks around uncomfortably at the luxurious boat for a moment before--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesco just stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesco is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat approaches a large stone house, Oxford Stone.

dialogues.speaker: A RED ROSE
dialogues.text: as it is cut from its bush by ink-stained hands.       We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford smells the rose, inhaling its essence. Then he turns and sees Francesco escorting Ben Jonson towards him. Before they reach him he glances at his wife ANNE De Vere (40's) who sits in the distance knitting with one of their daughter's, BRIDGET (17). Jonson is quite uncomfortable to be at such a grand place. Jonson CLEARS his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tudor rose. The most beautiful of flowers, don't you think? JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks to me to have quite a number of thorns, my lord. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it does.   So it does. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am told, my lord, that I owe my freedom to you. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is true. And it was quite hard to come by. One does not cross my father-in-law lightly. Jonson doesn't know who he is talking about. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord William Cecil. I have the questionable distinction of being married to his only daughter. Oxford looks over to his wife who watches them suspiciously. He begins to walk away forcing Jonson and Francesco to follow. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did, however, serve as helpful when I wrote to your jailers to release you in my father-in-law's name. Jonson suddenly looks worried and turns and looks back to Anne. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a panicked whisper) My lord-- I'm sorry, does that mean my release is not officially sanctioned? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be an idiot Jonson, of course it wasn't. (beat) But you are free, are you not? They have come to an entrance to a GARDEN MAZE and Anne watches them as they disappear into the maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford turns to Jonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoyed your little comedy last week, Jonson. You have potential, great potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's politics did seem to have quite an effect on the Tower. My father-in-law's men felt it quite seditious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Politics? My play had nothing to do with politics! It was just a simple comedy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That showed your betters as fools who go through life barely managing to get food from plate to mouth, were it not for the cleverness of their servants. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All art is political, Jonson. Otherwise it would just be decoration. And all artists have something to say, otherwise... they'd make shoes. And you're not a cobbler, are you, Jonson? As they enter the center of the maze, Oxford turns to his servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesco. Francesco steps forward and hands Jonson a leather bound manuscript. Jonson looks at it confused and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A play, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One you shall stage Bankside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stage? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under your name. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name, my lord? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't very well use my name, can I? I'm the seventeenth Earl of Oxford. The Lord Great Chamberlain of England, Viscount Bolebec, Lord Escales, Sandford and Badlesmere, etc, etc. No. I have a... reputation to protect. In my world, one does not write plays, Jonson. People like you do. Jonson tries not to be offended. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. My lord. You wrote an entire play, my lord. I know how difficult-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a play, Jonson, I've written many. No doubt, many more than you yourself. A good number performed at Court years ago, others never seen by a living soul. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want... me to apply my name to this play? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean you to put your name to all of them. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't look like I just gutted your pet dog, Jonson. I mean to make you the most popular-- and therefore the most monetarily successful-- playwright in all of London. Jonson pales.   This is a disaster for him. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you god speed and good morrow. Jonson looks down at the manuscript, reads a few lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord-- I really-- He looks up, but Oxford is gone, having left the maze without so much as a good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord? But before he can follow, Francesco tosses a leather pouch of coins at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is for your trouble, Signor Jonson. And your silence. If I hear you break that silence, then... not so good for Signor Jonson. And Francesco follows after his master as Jonson picks up the pouch, examining its contents. And then Jonson realizes he doesn't know how to get out of the maze. He chases after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   My lord?! I-- And he's lost. He looks this way and that, then picks a path (the wrong one).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil is standing at the opulent river   entrance to Cecil House, waiting for an enormous barge   docking. William Cecil (now 75) is at the front of the   barge, waiting to disembark. He constantly holds an    ornately carved white cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! I am gone for three days, and you somehow manage to let her spend all of them solely in the company of the Earl of Essex... Robert Cecil looks at him sharply.   How did he know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think because I was in London, I didn't know exactly what went on here in my absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is an Earl, father. I cannot deny him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not! You don't deny him anything. You find excuses. She is unwell, she is reading, she is seeing the Ambassador from Russia. For God's sake, use your imagination, Robert. Whatever will you do when I am gone? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will have to deal with Essex soon. His ambitions are becoming a nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Cecil enters an impressive hallway and turns to his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me about the play. Robert Cecil looks surprised for an instant that he knows about that as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It-- it was an anonymous gift. Essex insisted it be performed, just to spite me in front of Court...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he did. (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what was it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About? Some nonsense about fairies and cherubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And dancing asses? Robert looks surprised at his father who has stopped suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing, to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward... (to Robert Cecil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any idea what you have-- No, how could you... And he starts back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...    It was just a play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you know how long it took me to banish them from her presence? She adores them! Adores them! And Edward knows it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark my words, Robert, he has done this for a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purpose?    What purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking, to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What purpose indeed? (to Robert)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But through your carelessness I must now deal not only with Essex, but Edward as well. For whether in shadow or in person, Edward has returned to Court! And with that he slams the door shut. Robert Cecil walks over to a nearby window. Visibly upset he starts to stare out of the window and remembers...

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH A THIRD STORY WINDOW
dialogues.text: We see servants carrying big trunks. There are at least 120 men on horses. They all wear the Oxford's crest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is thirty years earlier. BOY ROBERT CECIL (now 9) is staring out of the window. His back must have been deformed either in utero or at birth, because even now he is hunchbacked. WILLIAM CECIL(O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more commanding) Robert! Come here. Finally Boy Robert Cecil turns and sees Young Oxford (now 17) entering the hallway with William Cecil and his wife and daughter, Young ANNE (15). In front of them, lined up, are several men whom we will learn are TUTORS. Boy Robert Cecil doesn't move. WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Young Oxford) I am sorry, my lord. But my son Robert prefers the company... of himself... Boy Robert Cecil watches as his father turns to his mother and sister. WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I present my wife, Lady Cecil, and my daughter, Anne. Young Anne curtsies. YOUNG ANNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry for your loss, my lord. The realm lost a great lord with your father's death. We hope you will be happy in our house-- BOY ROBERT CECIL (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to live here forever? Everybody turns and sees the odd hunchback child has finally come over. YOUNG OXFORD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Only until I reach my maturity. BOY ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the Queen has bade it so. (to Young Oxford) My lord, when we first met, you said you wished to become a great man of State. Both the Queen and I hope to make that so. (MORE) WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To that end, I have the honor of introducing you to your tutors. (indicates one of them) Seven to eight you shall be tutored in French by Mister Crane-- YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur. Ca me fait plaisir de vous connaitre. Master Crane bows his head. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine to ten is Greek with Mister Simmons. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Greek) Dalon, an d'ego, hoti mathamata ge esti ha trafo psychas. BOY ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Homer? YOUNG OXFORD (sharp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Plato. Boy Robert frowns at the correction. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight frown, then) And you know your uncle, Mister Golding, who has petitioned me to allow you to assist him in his translations of ancient Latin texts into English. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Latin) Continetne, ut spero, Ovidii Metamorphose? Mihi honori erit, patrue Mister Golding bows his head in appreciation. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then cosmography with Doctor Richards. Two to three is geography and history, and four to five fencing. William Cecil seems to have finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to William Cecil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And composition? Poetry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Puritan home, your grace. We believe such activities to be the worship of false idols, and therefore a sin before the eyes of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sin? But surely there must be room for beauty and art in life, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in this household.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Oxford is fencing with a tutor. He's quite good. In fact, he's better than the tutor, who is twice his age. Boy Robert Cecil casually watches as he plays chess against himself. Young Oxford, with a fierce, beautifully executed attack, disarms his tutor. The tutor's sword FLIES into the air, and hits--

dialogues.speaker: THE CHESS BOARD
dialogues.text: making the pieces scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy Robert Cecil looks up, his face furious, to see Young Oxford coming over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were losing anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was also winning. Young Oxford picks up the sword, throws it to his tutor, who catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I am going to one day succeed my father at the Queen's side. Not you. Young Oxford motions to go, then picks up the black king, and tosses it to Boy Robert Cecil, who can't catch it because of his deformity. It CLANGS on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later, the Young Oxford heads down the hall alone, heading for his rooms, his sword still in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: POEMS
dialogues.text: neatly written on parchment.   We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a SERVANT is looking at the poems, then quickly stuffing them into a bag. But then he HEARS footsteps coming. Panicked, he looks for someplace to hide-- a tapestry half covers a door-- he runs to it-- the door is locked! So he hides behind the tapestry just as the door opens, and Young Oxford enters. After a few steps, Young Oxford senses something amiss. Looks at his--

dialogues.speaker: WRITING DESK
dialogues.text: where the parchments are scattered.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OXFORD
dialogues.text: goes to his desk, picks up one of the pieces of parchment. It has poetry on it. His poetry. He goes through some other pages. And realizes other pages are missing. He becomes infuriated. He sees--

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE TAPESTRY
dialogues.text: Two feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Oxford CHARGES the tapestry, sword in hand.     He THRUSTS the sword THROUGH the tapestry. The man screams in agony as he falls. He doesn't just die, but screams and screams and screams. Young Oxford steps back-- half in horror... half in triumph. The SOUND of APPLAUSE takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three years later. Shakespeare is on stage, taking a bow. The audience is APPLAUDING and SCREAMING their approval of a performance that has just ended. He steps backwards--

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: --where Jonson stands holding the manuscript Oxford gave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How in blazes should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't even read it? And Shakespeare is drawn back--

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: --where he bows again, then steps--

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: --so Jonson can answer him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read a line or two-- I promised Henslowe I'd finish "Eastward Ho" by Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you say he's a nobleman? Jonson doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powerful?   Rich?? Jonson still doesn't answer, which is answer enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh, you have to do it then, don't you? And Shakespeare goes back on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson and Shakespeare are walking along Bankside, still mid-conversation. They pass all sorts of vendors selling fish, fresh water, food, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you Will-- I came to London to become a great poet, to, to, be the conscience of our times, the soul of our age! To change the world, not to become someone else's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change the world? With rhyme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, why not? Why can't a man change the world with words? Shakespeare laughs at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Oxford)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I can make you the most popular and the richest playwright in all of London." (takes a swig)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballocks! I can do that myself, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare is perusing the manuscript.   Some of the actors from the Rose are in the BG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's actually not half bad... Jonson takes a swig of ale, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not half--?! You're an actor, what in God's name do you know about writing?! He's an amateur, Will, a complete and utter amateur. Last week gardening, this week playwrighting, next week hawking. (takes another swig)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I won't do it. It would be an affront against the Muses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we musn't offend the muses, whatever we do. (thinks, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much money did you say he gave you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you think my name can be bought, if the number's great enough, do you? Shakespeare smiles enigmatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all... I think we should keep your good name quite intact, thank you very much. Jonson frowns, confused as we--

dialogues.speaker: A RED WIG
dialogues.text: as it is placed on the head of Elizabeth.   We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is behind an elaborately painted screen. Several ladies-in-waiting attend her, helping her get ready for the day. It's an intricate process. Make- up, multiple articles of clothing, jewelry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Philip of Spain sees the current Catholic revolt in Ireland as a weakness of ours. A weakness to be exploited.... Elizabeth's wig is being glued into place. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ireland?

dialogues.speaker: OF SCREEN AS NEEDED
dialogues.text: William Cecil hasn't realized that his son Robert has sneaked in the room behind him to listen in. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are rumors of his sending financial aid, and even troops. We must act quickly. (beat) We must replace the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and send additional troops immediately, majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Replace?   With whom? William Cecil hesitates slightly, then-- WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would recommend the Earl of Essex, your majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex?  To Ireland? (frowns) For how long? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as the present crisis warrants, majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. He cannot be spared. We feel his counsel is of greater import with each passing day. Not what William Cecil wanted to hear. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only recommend we send your most able subjects where they are most needed, majesty. (beat, a last-ditch effort)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip of Spain dreams still of taking your kingdom from you. (MORE) WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of burning you at the stake as a heretic. Give him a foot-hold in Ireland, and-- ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Essex? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex's martial abilities are, in my opinion, the only antidote to the plague of Philip. (clears his throat) Though, Essex would not, unfortunately, be able to remain in the Privy Council if he is in Ireland... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who would you advise to replace him? Three ladies-in-waiting approach with three different gown. Elizabeth studies them as: WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Robert Cecil. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is my own advisor first, my son second, majesty. His counsel has been invaluable to me, and no doubt will be to you as well. Elizabeth points to one of the dresses, and waves the handmaidens away. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes. We will send Essex to Ireland and place Robert on my Privy Council. But William's flash of victory is dampened by-- ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a play this last weekend, William. It made me think of... days long past. Of memories... long past. Long past. I should like to see more of them... Has Edward been happy, William? With your daughter? William Cecil doesn't answer. Instead he thinks, remembers, as we hear his younger voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdered!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty years earlier. William Cecil is standing in front of an enormous fireplace, pacing in a pique of anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By your own hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was stealing my poems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was doing my bidding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. As soon as Robert informed me that you were disobeying my express--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert?   Robert told-- William Cecil SLAMS his fists on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough! Thou shalt not worship false idols in my household! Your everlasting soul hangs in the balance. Not poems. Your soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My poems are my soul! William Cecil turns away in frustration as much as disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have placed me in a grave position, Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot have my reputation soiled by this regrettable lack of control on your part... No. I will not have it. We can claim self-defense, he drew sword first. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... I wish something in return. Young Oxford looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter is young, impressionable. She has feelings for you, Edward. It is to be expected, living in such close quarters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. For the last three years you have managed to seize much of my inheritance--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue, Edward, before you make a claim you cannot retract! I have been legally reimbursed for your education and living expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you suggest you be "reimbursed" the rest of my once considerable estates through your daughter's bed? William Cecil studies Young Oxford's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is how I suggest you keep your noble head from the executioner's block.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OXFORD
dialogues.text: stares at him.   The SOUND of CHURCH BELLS RINGING takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Young Oxford and Anne are being married by a bishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and in the fear of god, duly considering the causes for which matrimony was ordained. One was the procreation of children...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM CECIL
dialogues.text: appears triumphant.   He looks beaming over to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to be brought up in the fear and nurture of the Lord and praise of God. Secondly, it was ordained for a remedy against sin.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who presides over the whole affair. The first time we see a dress on her which makes her truly regal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirdly, for the mutual society, help and comfort, that the one ought to have of the other, both in prosperity and adversity, into the which holiest state these two persons present come now to be joined.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ALTAR
dialogues.text: Young Anne looks at her young husband, lovingly. Young Oxford is a bit overwhelmed and unsure of it all. And then we HEAR a trumpet BLARING, which takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-two years later. Vendors hawk food and drink as they walk through the audience.

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: Oxford sits, Francesco behind him, exhilarated by the scene below him.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: Marlowe, Dekker and Nashe are looking at their single- sheet programs. NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Henry V" by... No one? MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why would any of you admit to trying to better me in a historical drama? Comedy, yes, tragedy, perhaps. But never will one of you best me in historicals. Marlowe takes a swig of ale, and spots Jonson coming to join them. MARLOWE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or will we be seeing a most hysterical historical? Jonson sits next to Marlowe. MARLOWE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? Ben? Waiting to see how it's received before you lay claim?? Before Jonson can answer--

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: An actor, CONDELL (40's), dressed all in white (even his face is painted white) enters stage. He is "Prologue". He addresses the audience directly. "PROLOGUE"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for a muse of fire, that would ascend the brightest heaven of invention. A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, and monarchs to behold the swelling scene! Then should warlike Harry, like himself, assume the port of Mars, and at his heels should famine, sword, and fire crouch for his employment. Can this cockpit hold the vasty fields of France?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: Jonson seems surprised.   This is not what he expected. This is good.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE HOOVES
dialogues.text: as they POUND on cobblestone.   We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Southampton is riding his horse at full gallop through the countryside. About two dozen retainers follow, the first few with Southampton's coat-of-arms on flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later in the play. On stage, about 15 actors are in full battle armor. They include: "HENRY V", played by the actor called Spencer, "WESTMORELAND", "EXETER", "SALISBURY". All the men on stage now wear battle armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This day is called the feast of Crispian: he that outlives this day, and comes safe home, will stand a tip- toe when this day is named, and rouse him at the name of Crispian.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: Marlowe, Dekker, Nashe and Jonson all watch, obviously impressed. Nashe takes a swig of Ale.

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: Oxford watches, loving the stagecraft involved in the production.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He that shall see this day and live t'old age, will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors, and say 'To- morrow is Saint Crispian.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "Henry V" speaks to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars. The actor playing "Henry" kneels at the front of the stage. He speaks to the groundlings as though they are his troops. "HENRY V" (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.' Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot, but he'll remember with advantages what feats he did that day. This story shall the good man teach his son.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUNDLINGS
dialogues.text: become literally spellbound. "HENRY V" (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by, from this day to the ending of the world, but we in it shall be remembered; we few, we happy few, we band of brothers; for he to-day that sheds his blood with me shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile, this day shall gentle his condition: and gentlemen in England now a-bed shall think themselves accursed they were not here, and hold their man-hoods cheap whiles any speaks that fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day! The entire audience stands and CHEERS madly.

dialogues.speaker: OXFORD
dialogues.text: watches, with a pride he has never felt.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: The "wits" look at each other amazed.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "SALISBURY"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed. The French are bravely in their battles set and will with all expedience charge on us. "HENRY V"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All things are ready, if our minds be so. "WESTMORELAND"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know your places: God be with you all!

dialogues.speaker: THE "HUT"
dialogues.text: which is a round tower on top of the stage, contains several small cannons manned by stagehands. They shoot BLANK CANNON SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southampton and his retainers gallop through a City gate. Above the gate, the severed heads of murderers sit on pikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actors portraying French soldiers STORM the stage, swords brandished. "Henry" and his men begin fighting them, their swordplay elaborate and impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southampton and his entourage gallop over London Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battle rages on stage. One hardy audience member starts to actually ATTACK one of the French "soldiers" himself. He's quickly joined by a few comrades-- and it quickly becomes a madhouse; half play, half real fight, as more audience members join the "battle". The play quickly degenerates into a bloody brawl between actors and audience.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. ROSE THEATER
dialogues.text: Southampton arrives at the theater.   He jumps   off his horse, and hurries--

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: jumping two steps at a time. We HEAR the sound of APPLAUSE. The play is now over. Southampton hurries into--

dialogues.speaker: OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: He sees Oxford, who is applauding.    All the actors of the play are taking their bows. SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Cecil's convinced the Queen that only Essex can save Ireland from the Revolt. Oxford processes this. SOUTHAMPTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've pledged to go with him, Edward. We sail in an hour. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry-- SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask for your blessing, Edward. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I for one wish to see this anonymous colleague of ours. (stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playwright! Playwright!! Marlowe and others join in.   And--

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare, standing next to a small table of props, quickly dips his fingers in an inkwell to make them stained. He grabs a large feathered quill and tucks a piece of parchment under his arm, then hurries--

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: --where he bows deeply, loving the adulation.

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: SOUTHAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he is to be my king, then it is my sacred duty to be with him in battle. Oxford tries to understand Southampton, but then notices Shakespeare on stage. His mouth opens in shock, and he turns to look across the theater at--

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: who guiltily looks away.   Marlowe's mouth is open, his hands stop applauding.

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: Southampton is angered by Oxford's distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry to have disturbed your entertainment. And he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry-- Henry!! But the younger man is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare bows, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I... It's been... I, I, want to... thank my actors, whose great acting brought... my words... to life due to their most finest acting. Ah... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actor?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The multi-arched ceiling is painted blue with gold stars. Globes-- both terrestrial and astral-- abound. Jonson stands in front of a very angry Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actor for god's sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord, I thought that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You presumed to think? On my behalf? Whatever made you believe you had that prerogative? A beat.   Jonson is a bit afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord, your voice is completely different than mine. My, my, my characters are--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voice? You have no voice! That's why I chose you! (beat, softer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You at least kept my name from him? Jonson NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will continue to do so? Oxford studies him, believes him.   Then he opens a cabinet. In it, manuscript after manuscript are stacked.     Jonso looks behind him, stunned by the number. Oxford looks up and down the cabinet. He pulls one out, decides no, and puts it back, looking for just the right one... He pulls another out, then hands it to Jonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A romantic tragedy. In iambic pentameter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All, my lord? Is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson exits Oxford's study, still amazed at the manuscript as he walks. He passes ANNE, Oxford's wife (now 40's), who is on her way to the study with their eldest daughter, BRIDGET (17). She watches him go by and immediately realizes that she has seen him before. But she stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is writing at a desk as Anne enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that man?    I've seen him before. Oxford holds up a finger to prevent her from speaking while he finishes writing a thought. It's a long thought. Anne is obviously annoyed, and interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward-- we must discuss our Bridget's dowry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up - confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dowry? He remembers when he spies his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cannot go into marriage without a dowry that is becoming to the daughter of the Earl Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give her Brooke House and a hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred pounds? Father?     Mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is all we have to give at the moment. The matter over, Oxford goes back to his writing.
