dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward. Edward! Speak to me! Our family is in financial ruins, and, and you, you play the flute while Rome burns! Oxford turns. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nero fiddled whilst Rome burned. And then he goes back to writing. ANNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For god's sake, who cares Edward? When your own daughter can't even have a suitable dowry? She stares at him. ANNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My god, you're writing again, aren't you? After you agreed-- after my father expressly forbade it! Oxford turns to her, full of emotion OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne-- If you could have seen them-- the mob... They, they didn't just sit there like the reptilia of court, faces motionless, fangs momentarily retracted. No! They, they jumped on stage, they fought the French! A butcher-- he actually broke his arm! He was so-- ANNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!   Stop it at once!! Anne storms over and grabs the parchment from under him, and begins RIPPING it up. ANNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why!? Why must you write?! Why must you continue to humiliate this family? He stares at her, almost uncomprehendingly.   Then-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voices, Anne... The voices. I, I can't stop them... They, they come when I sleep, when I wake, when I sup, when I, I, I walk down a hall! The sweet longings of a maiden, the, the surging ambitions of a courtier, the foul designs of a murderer, the wretched pleas of his victims.    Only- - only when I put their words-- their voices-- to parchment are they cast loose, freed... Only then is my mind... quieted... at peace. Anne steps back, frightened of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... would go mad if I didn't write down the voices. She stares at him, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art thou possessed? He stares back at her.   A long beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Two households, both alike in dignity, In fair Verona, where we lay our scene"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare and Jonson are walking along London Bridge-- the only bridge that spanned the Thames at the time, it is a street lined with multi-storied buildings-- almost like a mall. Shakespeare caries and reads from a manuscript of "Romeo and Juliet"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "From ancient grudge break to new mutiny, Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean." (no longer reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible!! The whole bloody thing in verse?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really not that difficult, if you try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have you ever tried? Jonson gives him a sharp look, and pauses to pick some onions from a stand. Shakespeare notices a BUXOM BLONDE women selling apples at the next stand. SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (performing for the Blonde)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun. Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief, That thou her maid art far more fair than she." The Buxom Blonde smiles at Shakespeare seductively. SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jonson) I'll have little trouble parting the legs of barmaids after that performance! JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't play Romeo. Jonson leaves the stall, and continues down the street. Shakespeare hesitates, then gives the girl a dazzling smile. She smiles back, then Shakespeare runs after Jonson. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jonson) Why not? I won't let that oaf Spencer have another go at one of my roles. No-- only Will Shakespeare can pump the life into Romeo's veins. (grins at another passing girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his cod piece! (beat, desperate) Ben-- Ben! I'm an actor, every inch of me, down to my very toes... I want- - no, I need, crave-- to act. I can't just idle the day by with-- JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So bloody well act like a writer! And for God's sake, keep off the stage. Writers don't have time to act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A performance of "Romeo and Juliet". About a dozen actors are dancing. It is Act 1, Scene 5. "ROMEO", played by Spencer, is staring longingly at "Juliet". "Romeo" turns to his servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What lady's that, which doth enrich the hand of yonder knight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night like a rich jewel in an Ethiop's ear; beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear! The actor playing Romeo plays to the women in the audience. And

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMEN
dialogues.text: respond, eye lashes twittering.

dialogues.speaker: THE WITS
dialogues.text: Watch in awe!   Now they're all taking swigs of ale.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare mouthing silently the lines of "Romeo".

dialogues.speaker: IN OXFORD'S BOX
dialogues.text: Oxford watches the dance carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight! For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight years earlier. A dance is taking place. YOUNG OXFORD-- now 20 is dancing with Young Anne.     But his eyes are on: Young Elizabeth, who is dancing with the Spanish AMBASSADOR.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: seems less than interested in her dancing partner.    She STARES intently back at Young Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a natural change in the music, and all the dancers switch partners-- it's part of the dance. Young Oxford goes to Young Elizabeth, the Spanish Ambassador goes to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD
dialogues.text: stare into each others eyes as they dance the intricate moves. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord of Oxford. Elizabeth smiles. YOUNG ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We liked your play tonight very much. Your young King Henry reminded us of you. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he? YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rash, yet brave. A boy-- and yet a man. Fair on the eyes, fairer to the ear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much of the Court is watching this.   They can tell there are sparks between them. All the dancers change partners, including Elizabeth and Oxford. A few dance moves, and Oxford once again finds himself with Elizabeth. YOUNG ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are glad of your return from the continent. Two years is far too long to be without such excellent amusements. Young Oxford dips his head slightly in acknowledgment. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had known my absence would cause your grace so much... longing, I would have returned much-- much-- sooner. Was that a come-on?    Young Elizabeth decides to find out. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife must be much pleased by your presence once more at her side... Young Oxford glances over at--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANNE
dialogues.text: who is now dancing with the Spanish Ambassador. But she watches Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford with a great deal of jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM CECIL
dialogues.text: Follows his daughter's look. He doesn't like what he sees any more than Young Anne does.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD
dialogues.text: Still dancing. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she is, it is but a small comfort to me. I am returned only under my father-in-law's insistence. A beat as this sinks in. YOUNG ELIZABETH (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil had told me your match was one of love. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so he would wish. (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how could one ever love the moon, after having first seen the sun? He stares intensely into her eyes.    And she stares right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Ladies-in-waiting run onto the balcony to join Bessie, who is looking across the palace grounds, watching--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford, both on horseback, unaccompanied, trot over a small bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ladies-in-waiting giggle, but are interrupted by--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is her majesty? Bessie turns to William Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord. Her majesty went riding with the Earl of Oxford. The Ladies-in-waiting share knowing smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford share flirty glances, and then Young Elizabeth spurs her horse to a gallop, and dashes into the fog. Young Oxford immediately follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A servant places a silver plate filled with shucked oysters onto a table filled with quail, venison, wine, etc... Young Elizabeth sits across from Young Oxford.   It's just the two of them dining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And which country did you like the most on your travels, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Italy, your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why is that? The weather?       The food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No their theater, which they call la Commedia dell'arte. And, of course, the women. She raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were more... clear with their desires than our English ladies. When they want something, they take it. They do not wait to be taken...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door SLAMS open, and Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford dash in, ripping each others clothes off in the fireplace-lit room. Young Elizabeth gently pushes Young Oxford towards her throne... She kisses him. Then begin to make love. On the throne.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Postcoital, the fire still lit. Young Elizabeth is half asleep, half awake, nestled in furs in front of the fireplace... much like Titania in "Midsummer Night's Dream"... Young Oxford watches her as she stirs and wakes.      She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't decide. Are you Prince Hal...? Or Romeo? No. Benedick, maybe...? No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ELIZABETH (CONT'D) (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Puck YOUNG OXFORD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puck? YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Puck! She's only teasing. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but Puck would never fight for you in the Netherlands... YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, smiles) The Netherlands? But then she realizes he's serious, and the smile vanishes. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why not? It's an open secret on the continent that you support the rebels against Spain-- and that you are commissioning Englishmen to help their cause. Spain's loss is England's gain, is it not? Her eyes narrow as she studies his face. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this why you bedded me? For a commission? YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No-- of course not--    I-- She stands, wrapped in her sheets, furious at the thought of once more being used. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me.    Leave at once! A beat. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess-- YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you! How dare you!! I command you to leave my presence. And she steps back, waiting for him to exit. Young Oxford stands... and starts to approach her... He's nude, his back to us. She steps back, a bit stunned by his impertinence.   He steps towards her as-- YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O Mistress mine, where are you roaming? O stay and hear... your true-love's coming, That can-- (looks up and down her body)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --kiss both high and low... A bit stunned by his approach, she stumbles backwards on her sheets. YOUNG OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trip no further, pretty sweeting.... But he's sexy... and naked. And spouting poetry.     She stops retreating and allows his approach. YOUNG OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Journeys end in lovers' meeting-- Every wise man's son doth know. A small smile escapes her lips. YOUNG OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is love? 'tis not hereafter; Present mirth hath present laughter; What's to come is still unsure: He starts to kiss her neck.   Cautiously at first.   But she likes it. YOUNG OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In delay there lies no plenty-- Then come kiss me, Sweet-and-twenty, Youth's a stuff will not endure. She responds to him, melting from both his words and touch. They start to kiss deeply, passionately... And-
YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately) You will stay in England... And in... my chambers... The flash of disappointment on Young Oxford's face about that last bit is tempered by Young Elizabeth's sheet falling to the floor. They begin to make love passionately once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could do it if I wanted to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven years later. Jonson, Marlowe, Dekker and Nashe sit silently at a table, mugs of ale in hand. Having just returned from "Romeo and Juliet", all are a bit in shock. The actors from the perfomance are there as well in the BG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nashe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little drunk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A play in iambic, in iambic pen...in- bic-pentameter. It's not that hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you so? Have you ever tried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. But I could if I wanted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't all in verse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!   See!   Even easier! Shakespeare enters and makes a bee line for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henslowe wants "Romeo" to run a fortnight. (unbelievable news)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fortnight! Innkeeper! A round for everybody! Inkeeper!! (no response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy!!! And Shakespeare goes over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fortnight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maids love the romantic tragedies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely why I avoid them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, well. No worries. A one-trick pony. He'll never be able to do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of various plays:

dialogues.speaker: "TWELFTH NIGHT"
dialogues.text: Viola and Sebastian are reunited...

dialogues.speaker: "CAESAR"
dialogues.text: Caesar is attacked by Brutus, Cinna, Cassius, etc...

dialogues.speaker: "MACBETH"
dialogues.text: The witches are on stage. These three performances are INTER-CUT with:

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBILLS
dialogues.text: outside the Rose, announcing each play's title.      At first, Shakespeare's name is small, with each succeeding play his name gets bigger. And--

dialogues.speaker: AFTER EACH PERFORMANCE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare bows to the ever-increasing applause of his audience. He looks up to see the Mermaid's Wits all watching him with stony silence. And as each play is seen, Jonson and the rest of the Wits seem more and more depressed. And after each performance, Shakespeare seems to be greeted with more and more adulation. The MONTAGE ends with...

dialogues.speaker: A PLAYBILL
dialogues.text: in front of the theater announcing "William Shakespeare's Hamlet". Shakespeare's name is now above the title. We HEAR the audience howl with LAUGHTER as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actor playing "POLONIUS" does an obvious caricature of William Cecil, dressed in black with an exaggerated rendition of Cecil's beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over-acting) ...Beware of entrance to a quarrel, but being in, bear it that the opposed may beware of thee. Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice, take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth watches the same play at a court performance. We see Elizabeth smiling amused as "Polinous" continues his rant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy, but not expressed in fancy, rich, nor gaudy, for the apparel oft proclaims the man. This above all, to thine own self be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth absent mindedly starts to scratch her chest, irritated by some sort of itch, but still focused on the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson watches tight lipped... The character of GERTRUDE", the Queen, is joined by "HAMLET". "Polonius" is behind a curtain, listening in, and is seen by the audience. "Hamlet" appears enraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What wilt thou do? Thou wilt not murder me? Help, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (behind curtain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ho, help! "Hamlet" draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How now?   A rat? Dead, for a ducat, dead! "Hamlet" stabs "Polonius" through the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O, I am slain. "Polonius" emerges from behind the curtain, covered in pig's blood, and dies an anguished death. There is stunned silence in the audience. And then one lone Groundling CLAPS, then another, then the whole audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a day too soon for old Cecil!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is still scratching her chest, but more vigorously as some of the members of court give uncomfortable glances at each other over the death of William Cecil-- er "Polonius" onstage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O me, what hast thou done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, I know not. Is it the King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool, farewell! I took thee for thy better: take thy fortune; Thou find'st to be too busy is some danger. Leave wringing of your hands: peace! sit you down, And let me wring your heart; for so I shall, If it be made of penetrable stuff, If damned custom have not brass'd it so That it is proof and bulwark against sense. Elizabeth can't take the itching anymore. She RIPS open her bodice and violently scratches some sort of rash on her chest.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ROSE THEATER
dialogues.text: Oxford is in his usual box, but completely alone.   He has a smile of satisfaction on his lips while...

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: Looks over to Oxford with astonishment... While on stage the world sees for the first time "Hamlet" contemplating suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be, or not to be: that is the question: whether `tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles, and by opposing end them... Loud thunder and...

dialogues.speaker: RAIN STARTS TO FALL
dialogues.text: And as only the stage and the galleries are covered, the groundlings are pelted with the cold drops of water. But they stay. They stay. They cover themselves up, and silently watch on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...To die, to sleep- no more- and by a sleep to say we end the heartache, and the thousand natural shocks that flesh is heir to... The audience-- soaked, pelted with rain-- watches immobile. And then a again a loud thunder clap takes us to the end of the play...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKESPEARE
dialogues.text: Bows to the thunderous applause. It is still raining, but nobody wants to leave. While-

dialogues.speaker: THE MERMAID'S WITS
dialogues.text: watch in the crowd, a complex range of emotions, but jealousy and loathing at the top of the list.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: some of the audience members grab Shakespeare, and pull him on their shoulders, carrying him triumphantly out of the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe walks towards the Tower of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence....Marlowe is waiting patiently... He is sitting across from Pole, the Captain of the Guard, who is reading his report....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you certain of this? (almost confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Cecil was murdered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not literally, of course. He was a character, a fictional character. But the metaphor was clear for anyone to see. And see, they did. Pole reads more from the parchment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut it down? Pole continues to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not for me to decide... He brings out a pouch of coins, and tosses it across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your service to his lordship is once again greatly appreciated. Marlowe takes the pouch of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He butchered you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil is furious, pacing back and forth in front of William Cecil, who sits behind a large wooden desk. William Cecil is pale and sweaty-- he is deathly ill, and sits in a wooden chair with small spoked wheels attached to the legs-- sort of an Elizabethan wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only in front of Court! But the entire City as well! We must arrest this Shakespeare and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Robert, think. If he is really as popular as you say, we would only anger the mob. No. We must strike at Edward directly. William Cecil slowly-- and shakily-- bends down from his chair as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we cannot maintain our authority if the mob thinks us laughing stocks--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our authority comes from Elizabeth and from God! Elizabeth! Elizabeth is the key to all. Robert Cecil looks hurt by his father's anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gentler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert... You must think deeper. You must compensate. Compensate for your... malformations... with the gifts God did grant you... With cunning. With ruthlessness. William Ceci pushes a hidden button on the side of his desk-- a spring loaded secret drawer POPS open. Robert Cecil has never seen it before. Cecil produces a folded piece of parchment from the drawer, offers it to Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From King James of Scotland. Robert Cecil looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil is pushing William Cecil in his wheelchair. They are completely alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James knows of the Queen's affection for Essex... and the rumors of his birth. He is justly concerned. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will reply to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will reply to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am dying, Robert-- (before Robert can protest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both know this to be true. And I will not witness the next coronation.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil wheels his father in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me to my bed, my son. (Robert Cecil does so)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we are to secure your place at the side of the next king, you must get that king his throne, not I. A beat as this registers on Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will write to James that I am gravely ill, but that all is in hand. Much of the Privy Council has already secretly agreed to his ascension to the English throne due to your tireless, but secret, entreaties on his behalf. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then tell him Essex will not return from Ireland alive. Robert Cecil looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how kings are made, Robert. So it was with Elizabeth, and so it shall ever be. There were many rival claims to her throne, but none survived to make their claim. James must know that you will do the same for him, and he will reward you for it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we must do one thing more... William Cecil has a coughing fit-- reaches for a glass vial of medicine at his bedside-- takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Essex, Edward must be removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward? William Cecil is slowly falling asleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uses the tools at his disposal, as we use the tools at ours. But ours will win... as they always have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-- I don't understand, father.    What does Edward--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward seeks what we seek.   To choose the next King. Off Robert Cecil's surprised face we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am with child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty seven years earlier. Young Elizabeth is pacing, terribly agitated. Bessie, the lady-in-waiting we have seen constantly at her side is the only other person present. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you certain? Young Elizabeth turns to Bessie. BESSIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cycles have passed, my lord. William Cecil thinks. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to marry him... William Cecil looks startled. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry him, your grace? He is already married. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do what I will. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you? She gives him a sharp look. WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the Catholic princes of Europe wish to topple you and end your Protestant reign... The only things that stop them are the channel, and the hope that they might marry you, and thereby achieve your realm through other means. Young Elizabeth hears him, thinks on it, then begins pacing again. YOUNG ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him... WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you risk your throne for him? Would you risk England for him? He knows the answer to that. WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must do as we have done before... You must go on Progress, somewhere isolated, accompanied by only those whom you most trust. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the birth, I will find a suitable house for the child to be reared in. Young Elizabeth is uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Edward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple, cold space, like William Cecil himself. William Cecil is alone in prayer. A few beats, then he senses he is not alone. He turns and sees Young Oxford (still 20).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't see me! I've gone to her chambers three times, and she will not receive me. And now she's gone! William Cecil regards Young Oxford for a beat, then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's on Progress. With this he leaves the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Oxford runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?   Where did she go? William Cecil is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say to her? Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen does not ask for my advice about matters of the heart, Edward. If she had, she hardly would have chosen you for her pleasure. He has a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have known her eye would move elsewhere, Edward. It always has. You are neither the first, nor the last, of her lovers. Young Oxford looks up at him like a bucket of cold water has hit him. William Cecil stops. He looks at Oxford with a stern face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to my daughter, Edward. She will accept you with open arms, as she always has. Behave as your great title demands you behave. Tend to your estates, your investments. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And make me a grandson, an heir! Off Young Oxford's pained expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven years later. Jonson is alone, trying to write at a small table, though it's obvious from his fits and starts and crossing outs that he is having difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's difficult to write, isn't it? After watching something like "Hamlet"... Jonson looks up. Marlowe sits, uninvited.    Jonson looks annoyed at the interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen you watch him. Will. During a performance. It eats at you... at your soul... Jonson stares at him, his answer obvious. MARLOWE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think Will hasn't been arrested? You or I make the slightest joke about a nobleman of no consequence, and we find ourselves in a cell quicker than a fart spreads in the trade winds. Will-- he murders a caricature of old William Cecil himself, and still whores all the way to Westminster and back. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Perhaps they haven't noticed.. Jonson gets up and walks towards the door. MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made sure they did... Jonson turns around. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You informed on one of your own?   To the Tower? MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch who you judge, Ben, for as God is my witness, you may well find yourself doing the same before you meet your maker. We do what we have to, to survive, and survive well, in this life. All of us. And Will is definitely not one of us. You know he's illiterate, don't you? Jonson is stunned. MARLOWE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Oh, he can read well enough-- how else could he learn his lines? But the man never actually learned to form his letters. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here, Kit? MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) So who did write it? You?   No.    You'd take credit for it. No... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be someone who wants their anonymity protected. Someone who might even pay to have it protected. Jonson is getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nobleman. Jonson looks up.   Marlowe smiles, knowing he is closer to the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But which?    You know, don't you, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've had too much to drink, Kit. You're beginning to sound like one of your plays. Jonson stands and hurries out of the Tavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson heads down the street, Marlowe chasing after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben! Tell me. We can go to him together. Guarantee his anonymity... for a price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reported on me as well, didn't you, Kit? Last year. That's why I was arrested, wasn't it? Because you went to the Tower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, Ben... I had nothing to do with that. Jonson studies Marlowe for a beat and then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben-- I'll just go to Will! He'll tell me because he has so much more to lose than you. Fame. Fortune. And you'll profit nothing from it. Nothing! But Jonson is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A military encampment with dozens of tents on a cliff by the Irish seaside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex's tent is larger, and guarded. An OLD SERVANT carrying a tray with a silver pitcher approaches. A guard opens the tent for him to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex is having a Council of War with his generals and senior officers, including Southampton. They all stand around a table, consulting a map of Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Rebels have stripped the northern borders... Then we must march south... and take Cahir Castle... The SERVANT stays in the background as he pours wine into various goblets. Southampton notices him-- the servant's hand shakes as he pours the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clears throat, uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord. `Tis a well-defended fortress.    Two thousand men at least. We cannot-- Southampton notices the Servant's shaking hand slipping into a pocket as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what would you have me do? Spend the entire spring encamped? I am sent to Ireland to end this infernal rebellion, not idle my days with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert! In an instant Southampton draws a silver engraved pistol and SHOOTS the servant! Everyone is shocked-- but then we see:

dialogues.speaker: THE SERVANT
dialogues.text: had drawn his own, small wooden pistol.

dialogues.speaker: ESSEX
dialogues.text: shares a look with Southampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Establish. A foggy day. In the Foreground we see the maze. Oxford and his fencing master, BEAULIEU (20's) are in the center of the maze dueling with rapiers for exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wear outfits that are slightly more protective than ornamental. They duel for a few moments, and then Oxford TOUCHES Beaulieu's shoulder. The speak entirely in French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point! Oxford backs off, as does the fencing master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bien. Faisons du travail... le Coup droit d'autoritГ©?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mais oui, mon seigneur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bien.    En garde! And they once again begin to duel. But we quickly surmise something is amiss. Beaulieu is much more aggressive than he was before. Oxford realizes it, but is an expert swordsman, and defends himself well. And then Beaulieu aggressively moves forward, and STABS Oxford in the leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qu'est ce que vous faites? But Oxford has little chance to react, because Beaulieu continues his attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaulieu?    Beaulieu?! This has become an assassination attempt, not an exercise.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE OF THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Francesco is entering the maze with a silver tray carrying a pitcher and two goblets.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER OF THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Though wounded, Oxford is a superior swordsman. And he begins his own attack-- with a ferocity that surprises Beaulieu.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Francesco heads for the center as--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Oxford PIERCES Beaulieu's heart with his rapier, and Beaulieu SCREAMS--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Francesco hears the scream, and starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor?    Signor?!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE
dialogues.text: Oxford collapses as Francesco rushes in. FRANCESCO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor? Mio dio! Signor! What has happened-- Oxford checks his leg wound, and glances at the dead Beaulieu. He tries to wave off Franceso's aid, but to no avail as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaulieu-- he, he tried to kill me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson, slightly drunk, walks down a street, a whore under his arm, and notices a commotion up ahead: people talking by an alley near the Mermaid's tavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a passer-by)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all that, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body... Jonson peers over and sees:

dialogues.speaker: A BODY
dialogues.text: on its back in the alley. Someone turns it over.    It's MARLOWE, a dried stab-wound in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have been a cut-purse. Nowhere's bloody safe anymore, I'll tell you that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, open air theater where a chained bear is being led around the theater. A set of mastiffs are being led on the opposite side of the theater. The spectators are unruly, loudly making bets for the mauling to come. Jonson is among them, taking a look at the bear, deciding whether to bet on it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson! Sired by the great Arthur himself! No dog's yet been bred that can take him down! Shakespeare suddenly sits next Jonson hardly notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More--? You already make more than any playwright Bankside. BEAR BAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then here, good friends, I bring you a pack of dogs so fierce, so dangerous, that Medusa herself would shrink in fear! SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to build my own theater, Ben, one that fits the scale of my work-- Jonson suddenly turns to him. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your work? BEAR BAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a one has had a morsel of food in a week! Bred by the great John Sinclow! A MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourpence on three dogs! SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They insist only a gentleman can own the land. ANOTHER MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shilling on four! SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bribes are outrageous, but I found some one who will make me a coat-of-arms, and change the Stratford lists for me. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. ANOTHER MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight shillings on six dogs!   Eight shillings on six dogs! JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that bet!!   Eight shillings on the bear, six dogs! ANOTHER MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done! SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad bet, that. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Shakespeare) You'll have to make do with what you've got. I won't be your beggar. Shakespeare gives him a look to kill. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a request, Ben.   I'll have more money. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what? You'll slit my throat like you did Kit's? MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release the dogs!   Release the dogs! Shakespeare shows no reaction. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he went to see you last night, Will. And I know he was planning to expose you if you didn't agree to his terms.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PIT
dialogues.text: The bear baiting begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare stares at Jonson. SHAKESPEARE (dead serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad, Ben. Kit was my friend. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, Will. You kill me off too, and you won't have any good plays to act in after this is all done. Some of the spectators BOO while others CHEER, and-- SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have my guineas, Ben. One way or another, I'll have my guineas. And he gets up and leaves as the--

dialogues.speaker: DOGS
dialogues.text: start to go for the bear's throat.     Thge cheering goes a roar as we--

dialogues.speaker: SHAKESPEARE
dialogues.text: Wears a beard and fake nose. He tries to stay hidden so Jonson doesn't see him. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is waiting not far from him by a stand and drinks an ale. Then Oxford's servant, Francesco, appears. After the two men have exchanged couple of words, Francesco gives Jonson a leather folder containing a manuscript and a purse jingling with coin. Jonson takes them and leaves. Jonson safely gone, Shakespeare starts to follow Francesco who heads back over the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare is in a small boat following Francesco, who is in Oxford's boat. They head towards Oxford Stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare watches as Francesco enters Oxford Stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare is waiting, clearly uncomfortable. It's not the kind of room he's used to being in. He holds his wig and his nose. A door opens, and Oxford enters, walking on a stick because of his leg injury. He is followed by his servant, Francesco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! You are the famous Shakespeare whose labors I have enjoyed so much. I am at your service, sir. Shakespeare is uncomfortable. He wasn't expecting Oxford himself. Then he just goes for it. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord-- I- I need more money. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) I beg your pardon? SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My expenses have, ah, aggrandized... since this all began. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Aggrandized"? SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if, if your lordship doesn't agree to an increase in my, ah, fee, I shall be forced to make certain... facts public. FRANCESCO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any idea to whom you are speaking? SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am addressing the writer of Hamlet... of Juliet and her Romeo.   Am I not? Oxford is silent. Francesco goes to physically eject Shakespeare from the room. FRANCESCO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. Get out! How dare you insult my master in-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! (beat) How much? Shakespeare looks at Francesco, then Oxford. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred pounds. A year. FRANCESCO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay him. Francesco is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient, in Italian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pagalo! Shakespeare smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare exits, tossing a leather pouch filled with coins. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford watches Shakespeare walk down the road through a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me for speaking of things above my place or understanding, signor. But... Is this wise? They have already tried to kill you once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisdom, Francesco, is a quality I have unfortunately never possessed... Francesco stares at Oxford who is deep in thought. The sound of heated love making takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five years earlier. Young Oxford (now 25 and with a beard) is making love to someone. We can't tell who at first, and assume it is Elizabeth. And then we see, it's BESSIE, Young Elizabeth's lady-in-waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later, post-coital. A fire is burning, and Bessie is finishing dressing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward... You know she would be furious if she found out about this... Young Oxford doesn't answer. He is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   She abandoned me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know, do you? He looks at her quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen.   She had your child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage drives towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Anne de Vere holds her sleeping daughter in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie carefully closes Oxford's bedroom door and suddenly freezes. She turns and sees Young Oxford's wife with her little daughter at her side standing in the hallway staring at her. For a moment nobody dares to move, then Bessie rushes off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot be certain, majesty, when the... relationship began.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Elizabeth looks out a window, obviously distressed. William Cecil is across from her, his face tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sometime soon after your return to Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They-- they haven't been very discreet, majesty. I presume he wanted you to know. To... to hurt you. She is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, there is more. The lady is pregnant. Young Elizabeth freezes, stunned.   Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest them.    Arrest them both! William Cecil bows and exits. Now alone, Young Elizabeth lets her emotions out.   She picks up a vase and THROWS it into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high above, we see a carriage arrive.    It stops, and William Cecil gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Oxford (now 26) is looking out a window at the river beyond. He has been imprisoned for some months. His beard has become ragged, his clothes have seen better days. William Cecil enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your whore gave birth last week. Young Oxford turns to William Cecil. The stare at each other for a beat. WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen has decided to release you. It seems time does indeed heal all wounds. (beat) These are her conditions for your release. One. You will not acknowledge the child. Two. You will never see the mother again. Three. You will avoid Court at all costs. Her majesty would prefer not to be reminded of you in any way ever again. A beat as Young Oxford thinks on all this. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banished...? WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You have the freedom of the kingdom. Just not of the Court. (beat) Those are her terms. Here are mine. You will go back to my daughter. You will make some effort to make her happy and you will finally act according to your station in life, and accept the responsibilities of your great title. Oxford reluctantly NODS.    William Cecil goes to leave. YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord!     I, too, have a condition. William Cecil turns. YOUNG OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go back to your daughter if... You tell me the name of the child. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if the whore has even delivered the-- YOUNG OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   The other one. Cecil's face goes to stone. WILLIAM CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other one? (realizing) Who told you? Cecil is obviously annoyed by this development.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go back to your daughter. I will make you as many grandchildren as she can bare... William Cecil thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or I can remain here... William Cecil decides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no record of his true birth, no trail that leads to you, or the... mother. His foster parents never knew the truth, and both are now dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make even a hint of this to the child, or anyone else, and this agreement is void, and I'll see your head on the block within a fortnight. And the boy's as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a boy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Oxford (cleaned up) is watching a BOY about five years old dueling with a tutor. The boy is quite good. The boy notices Young Oxford, and stops duelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Young Oxford smiles at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Edward, the Earl of Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... The Boy bows, a serious expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me one day you're to be an Earl as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall be the Earl of Southampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, we shall be Earls together, shan't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five years later. William Cecil's body is in state, in his coffin, in the center of the apse.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: looking completely stricken, approaches the coffin, holding Cecil's white cane. She places it at his side. In the background we hear the Archbishop of Canterbury reading from the bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return to the earth: for out of it wast thou taken, because thou art dust, and to dust shalt thou return...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT CECIL
dialogues.text: scans the room, to see how it is all playing out.

dialogues.speaker: OXFORD
dialogues.text: watches stoically, his wife and children at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral over, Elizabeth exits the portal of Westminster Abbey and heads to her carriage. A huge crowd of mourners has assembled. Robert Cecil steps into place right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wish to recall Essex from Ireland... Robert Cecil is instantly concerned, but hides it well. They continue to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We feel a terrible void, now that your father is no longer at our side... Robert Cecil bows his head as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wise decision, your majesty. If nothing else, it will give him an opportunity to respond to all these rumors. Still walking, she turns to him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, majesty, I thought you'd heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex is in negotiations with Philip of Spain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace is at hand. We know this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty-- it is said that Essex has promised Phillip all of Catholic Ireland in return for... He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In return for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spain's support of Essex's claim to the throne of England... They have arrived at her carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, as of yet, just rumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring him to me, William.   Bring him to me at once!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, majesty. Elizabeth stares at him for an instant, then gets into her carriage, unsure of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's death has been a great loss for us all... She ignores him, trying to collect herself. Robert Cecil turns to the driver, NODS, and the carriage takes off. As soon as it is away, Robert Cecil turns and some in the crowd of commoners begin to BOO at him.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE HOOVES
dialogues.text: as they gallop over emerald green grasses.   We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of horsemen gallop into Essex's camp. A MESSENGER jumps off his horse and heads for Essex's tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Essex and Southampton are having dinner as the messenger enters. He bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... He hands him a sealed envelope. Essex takes it, begins to read. Frowns, SLAMS the parchment down. He looks into the distance, trying to process what he's just read. Southampton picks up the parchment and begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't believe this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, can't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Robert Cecil. He failed to kill you, now he tries to kill your name. Essex heads for the flap of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We leave with the tide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare enters the tavern carrying a rolled up parchment. He passes various actors drinking, then hurries over to Jonson, Nashe and Dekker, who are deep in drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got it! Shakespeare unravels the parchment.   He puts it on the table with a flourish. It shows a coat-of-arms containing a spear and a falcon. The colors are numerous, and garish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The herald just finished it not an hour ago. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Everyone is confused by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite... colorful. DEKKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in blazes is it? SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My coat-of-arms! It cost a bloody fortune, but, by god, you can call me gentleman now! Jonson looks over at Shakespeare. Shakespeare locks eyes with him, but looks away, ashamed of something. DEKKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't quite make out the motto... Non sanz... Non... SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Non sanz droict". NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not without-- JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!? Not without right? (beat) You went to him, didn't you? You lying knave-- you went to him! Shakespeare doesn't want to discuss this with the others present. SHAKESPEARE (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben.   Ben! Let me buy you a-- He grabs Jonson's shoulder, but Jonson pushes him away. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You've already killed off one competitor. Now you want another dead as well? Shakespeare looks at the confused Nashe and Dekker nervously. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.   Ben, we should really-- JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swore to him I wouldn't tell you his name. Swore it! Do you have any idea what he might do to me? Do you? (to Nashe) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not even a writer you know. He can't even--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben-- you've had too much to drink. Shakespeare grabs Jonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhand me! Shakespeare backs off. Jonson pulls out a piece of parchment from his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! (looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quill! A quill! Nashe and Dekker look at each other, slightly embarrassed. Jonson finds a quill deep in his pants. He thrusts it at Will, who ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the parchment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Will. Write something for us. Now. Go on! Amaze us with your verse. Your wit! No? Try astounding us with the letter "E". Or an "I"-- it's just a straight line! Shakespeare stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got any ink. And he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southampton and Essex are on horseback, followed by several dozen armed retainers, GALLOPING towards the city of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party rides into the first gate. The palace is the city residence of the Queen, and is at the edge of the City. Essex and Southampton jump off their horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex and Southampton walk quickly down the long hallway, opening door after door. Servants scurry behind them, terrified of the intrusion, trying to stop them. They open the doors into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies-in-waiting scream in fear when they see the two men in battle gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Southampton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me. And he continues on into--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: --where Elizabeth is still dressing, putting on make- up, etc. She is NOT wearing her wig, and is only wearing her undergarments. She looks quite ugly. She turns to see Essex, shocked at his intrusion. Essex FREEZES.   He knows he has just made an enormous faux-pas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I, I... She stares at him, horrified to be seen in such a manner. The she regains her composure and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out!   Out!!! He steps back in horror-- not at her appearance, but what he has just done. The doors SLAM in front of him as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insolence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, now dressed and wearing her wig on her throne, is raging at Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in God's name does he think he is? Abandoning his post without my leave! She begins to absent-mindedly unbutton the top of her bodice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming into our presence in such a manner, neither announced nor invited, half his army in my courtyard. He's gone mad... mad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Unfortunately for us, your majesty, he is quite sane. He simply believes he is your royal equal. She turns to him sharply, furious at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like an armed camp, with part of Essex's army encamped in the front courtyard. The soldiers are all tense. Oxford, followed only by Francesco, rides into the courtyard. He is immediately surrounded by armed men, their muskets pointed at him. Oxford raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Edward, Earl of Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward!   Edward! Thank god you're here. Southampton comes towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth has revoked all of his royal licenses! She believes every lie Cecil tells about him. (seeing Oxford's wound)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward? What happened to your leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Oxford continues towards the door. Southampton follows, his concern for Oxford's wound noticeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford, Southampton and Essex are alone. Oxford is sitting in a chair, while Essex paces impatiently, Southampton standing between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't accept my letters. I cannot get to her. Cecil plans to arrest me any day. I know it. (beat and more determined)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that won't be as easy as he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight him in London, and you only validate every rumor and lie Cecil has ever told about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do you suggest I do? Let myself be arrested so I can be tried and executed for crimes I did not commit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I will go to Elizabeth, myself, alone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Cecil won't let her see a letter without reading it first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't send her a letter.   I will send her a book. Essex looks confused, but Oxford ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will call for me. And while I am with her, you will come-- not with an army, not with swords, but with her loyal subjects. The cobblers, the tinkers, the bricklayers of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All, all calling for Robert Cecil's banishment from Court. Words, Robert, words, will prevail with her, not swords. Essex looks unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the mob?    How will I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave that to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is in his rooms, writing feverishly by candlelight. He completes a thought... closes the manuscript... writes down the title with a flourish: The Tragedie of Richard III

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room for the whores to take their tricks.    Small, with nothing much beyond a straw bed. Shakespeare is bedding a buxom young lady. And then the door OPENS. Francesco enters, and Oxford follows, holding a manuscript. Shakespeare looks shocked. She starts to SCREAM and yell as she pulls a sheet to cover herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the whore)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue, whore, and get out! She does so as Oxford walks over to Shakespeare. He tosses the manuscript to him. Shakespeare starts to look at it. The whore is partially dressed, so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the whore)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out, woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi.   `Oo's going to pay me then? Shakespeare gives a look to Oxford-- he certainly isn't going to pay for it. Oxford nods to Francesco, who gives the whore a few coins. She smiles, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall begin rehearsals immediately. But it is not to be performed until I tell you. And you may only have a day's notice. Shakespeare looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be expensive-- keeping all the actors ready. Having the props made but not-- Oxford tosses a very large pouch of coins at him, and then begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and congratulations. You've had an epic poem published today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Published? You mean like in a book? Renaissance MUSIC BEGINS as we--

dialogues.speaker: A PIECE OF PAPER
dialogues.text: as a printer presses down the press onto it. The title page is printed in front of us. It's called "Venus and Adonis". A MONTAGE BEGINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the printer brings the page out from the press and checks it for proper alignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `The boar!' quoth she; whereat a sudden pale, Like lawn being spread upon the blushing rose... Usurps her cheek; she trembles at his tale,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on his neck her yoking arms she throws: The printer nods his approval...   The poem continues with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare exits the Print Shop, continuing to read the book, now out-loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sinketh down, still hanging by his neck, He on her belly falls, she on her back. (not quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like this...

dialogues.speaker: A COVER OF "VENUS AND ADONIS"
dialogues.text: that is held by a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fondling,' she saith, I'll be a park, and thou shalt be my deer; Feed where thou wilt, on mountain or in dale: We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LADY-IN-WAITING is reading out loud to other Ladies. They listen giggling now and then. We only see them from the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graze on my lips; and if those hills be dry, Stray lower, where the pleasant fountains lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Seeds spring from seeds, and beauty breedeth beauty; Thou wast begot; to beget is thy duty. By law of nature thou art bound to breed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up and see--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: standing across the room.   How much has she heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all stand abruptly, worried. The women who was reading the book puts it down on a table. Elizabeth silently walks over to them, and picks up the book. She opens it as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil walks down the long hall, heading for an audience with the queen. Two guards open a door, letting him into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is looking out the window. It's raining outside. She is NOT wearing her wig, not much make-up, and looks quite... odd. Robert Cecil enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) You find me disgusting, don't you? Repugnant. Wrinkled?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, you are the sun, majesty.   The glory of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil shuts his mouth. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it so hard to believe that once I was young? That I was... beautiful? Your father knew me as such... (beat) You have read the book? She doesn't have to say which one. Robert Cecil sees a copy of "Venus and Adonis" on a table. He NODS. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He writes to me. To remind me of that beauty. That love. How I... took him. How I... adored him... Robert Cecil knows to be silent.   She looks out the window. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throaty, sexually) Graze on my lips; and if those hills be dry, Stray lower, where the pleasant fountains lie... She smiles seductively, transported in time. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been foolish. Proud. Yes. Too proud. Gloriana... The Virgin Queen... A statue. Bloodless. (beat) "Thou wast begot; to beget is thy duty. By law of nature thou art bound to breed, That thine may live when thou thyself art dead"... (beat) Your father told you of the child? A beat. ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hint of a smile) Which one, your majesty? Elizabeth's eyes flare in anger for an instant, then she regains composure. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His.   Mine.   He still lives? Robert Cecil nods. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was well placed? A nobleman? ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yes... your majesty. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Robert Cecil hesitates. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am your Queen! Now who is my son!!? ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His grace, the Earl of... Southampton, your majesty. She seems surprised. Perhaps she was expecting Essex. But then she smiles, and NODS in approval. CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty... You are not having doubts about James of Scotland succeeding you, are you? Elizabeth goes into a rage. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James?! He is the son of Mary! She plotted and schemed to steal the throne from under me! No son of hers will rule while a yet Tudor lives! Robert Cecil is surprised by her fury. He bows his head as Elizabeth tries to collect herself. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will decide what is best for my kingdom! Not you! Not you!! (calmer) I have bid Edward to come to me on my return to London on Monday next. It is decided. She says no more, the audience over. Robert Cecil hesitates, and then she glares at him... He bows and exits, the fury on his face plain. Elizabeth looks at her own reflection in the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, in spite of death, I shall survive, In that, my likeness still is left alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Jonson walks with a manuscript in his hands. He stops for a moment when he sees the new Globe theater. Workers are still painting the walls. He pauses when he sees a poster in front advertising a performance of "Richard III" on Monday next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson sticks his head in and takes in the glorious new theater Shakespeare and Burbage have built. The actor Condell is on stage, rehearsing the character of "Gloucester". He walks on stage with a limp, and has a large hump on his back. He is a caricature of Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in character)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, nor made to court an amorous looking-glass... Richard BURBAGE, the theater's stage manager, is watching his performance with Spencer and a group of actors. Jonson stops and watches the rehearsal for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in character)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time into this breathing world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good part, that... "GLOUCESTER"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and that so lamely and unfashionable that dogs bark at me as I halt by them. (out of character) Is this wise? BURBAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only the one performance.   Go on! "GLOUCESTER"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a drink... And "Gloucester" heads backstage. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Burbage) Burbage. Wonderful theater. Wonderful! The best Bankside! But only one performance? Is it that bad? BURBAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly, it's Will's new play. Richard the Third. We've been hired to perform it free to the public. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free? BURBAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. Some anonymous nobleman paid for everything. God knows Will never would.   Been rehearsing all week, just found out this morning, we go up next Monday. Jonson thinks a beat-- that's odd-- but then holds up his manuscript. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) My best so far. I guarantee more than one performance. Though I'll not pay for the tickets myself. (winks) No need to. BURBAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ben... Jonson looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will... He's part owner... I'm sorry Ben, but I had to agree no Jonson plays at the Globe... Ever. Jonson is in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is deep in drink, by himself.   He listens as patrons of the bar say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a woman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doin' tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You askin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Managed to get two tickets to Shakespeare's latest. Cost me a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballocks, did it! They're giving them away free. Some of the actors from the rehearsal enter, all jolly and excited. They head for the bar. They are: The ACTOR WHO PLAYED "GLOUCESTER", Spencer, Pope, Heminge, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best villain in the history of theater, Richard the Third. No doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.    Better than Mephistopheles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt! Your Marlowe-- god rest his soul-- is fine for your everyday scalawag, and your Jonson won't even try the hard drama. No, this is Shakespeare, for god's sake! The man knows drama. I tell you, not even the Greeks compare! (toasting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Shakespeare! And villainy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Shakespeare! And villainy! Jonson gets up, furious, and exits, quite drunk.     The actors don't even notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson stumbles down the streets, alone, deep in his own private hell. It's raining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy a tumble? Only sixpence! Jonson waves her off.     He looks up and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tower of London. He makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson sits in the same spot where Marlowe was sitting earlier. And he hates himself for it. Rain drips down the windows. Pole looks up from some papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got all day, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... There is a-- there is a play to be performed... on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's many plays to be performed next Monday, isn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord, but this one is to be performed one performance, and one performance only. On Monday. All Bankside is talking of it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The History of King Richard the Third. By William Shakespeare. Pole is confused.   So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kills his brother the king, and half the royal family to get the throne for himself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who Richard the Third was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course you do. But in William Shakespeare's version, he is played as a hunch-back. Pole realizes this is significant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil has prayed all night. His lips silently move in a prayer for a miracle. When Pole appears he doesn't stop his prayer. Only after Pole whispers in his ear does he stop and look slowly up to the simple cross and close his eyes in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high, high above a city of 200,000 souls. It's a beautiful sunny day, but black storm clouds are on the horizon. All of London is on its feet. They all are on their way to Bankside. The London Bridge is crammed one way. The River Thames is full of many small boats of theatergoers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that a huge crowd has formed in front of the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is busy, preparing for the performance; actors, stage-hands, etc... Shakespeare adjusts an actor's costume when Burbage walks up besides him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to turn `em away by the hundreds! Look! Never seen anything quite like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And both men look out the curtains to the crowd outside. The theater is full to the last seat. The people are crammed together like sardines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is being dressed in front of a mirror...    His finest clothes... Powder to face... Francesco assists him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is leaning against the edge of the balustrade, watching the Groundlings fill in. He bites his nails nervous. Nashe joins him as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! I heard the Earl of Essex paid for this whole performance! Man's never even been to the theater, and still he's heard of Will--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dekker also joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex!? Impossible. My cousin's one of his men-at-arms. Hasn't been paid in weeks. They're all just sitting there, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting?     Waiting for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wants to have an audience with the Queen. As if Cecil would ever let Essex near her now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the mass, Cecil in favor, Essex out! Who can keep up with it all!? (takes a swig)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zounds, I tire of politics, politics, politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is in a long-boat, headed for Whitehall Palace. The oars of the boat cut neatly and silently into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is doing her toilette. She seems excited like a school girl before her first date. Her Ladies in waiting are attending to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience HUSHES as--

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
