dialogues.text: "GLOUCESTER", the future Richard III, enters. He is hunch-backed, and looks as much like Robert Cecil as possible in terms of beard and costume. First the people are in stunned silence, but then like magic the hissing starts. It is followed by more hissing and the first boos. The actor playing Gloucester nervously looks around...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: Dekker seems surprised at the similarity to Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nashe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired of politics are you? Seems you picked the wrong day to come to the theater, then... Jonson gives Dekker a sharp look.   What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: "Gloucester" addresses the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York. Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front.... The hissing and booing has swelled so strong that the actor stops for a moment. But then he finds the courage again to continue. Jonson looks down at the Groundling's reaction, and spots--

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCO
dialogues.text: in the audience. But among the Groundlings, not in Oxford's usual box seat.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: looks over to Oxford's box.   It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and now instead of mounting barded steeds to fright the souls of fearful adversaries, he capers nimbly in a lady's chamber to the lascivious pleasing of a lute. But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, nor made to court an amorous looking- glass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil watches himself in a mirror as armor is placed on him by servants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time into this breathing world,....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge crowd has stayed in front of the Globe. It seems they are waiting for something. We hear hissing and booing from the crowd inside the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and that so lamely and unfashionable that dogs bark at me as I halt by them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, "Gloucester: continues despite the concert of hissing and booing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover, I am determined to prove a villain and hate the idle pleasures of these days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex mounts his horse, Southampton at his side. Their sixty or so men behind them ready for the march to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward knows what he is doing...      Does he not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He promised us a mob. They'll be here. Essex looks concerned, but says no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The servant tightens the last strap of Robert Cecil's armor. He smiles at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plots have I laid!

dialogues.speaker: CANNONS DRAWN BY HORSES
dialogues.text: as they roll down a cobbled street.   We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers move people and carts off the street. Others put CANNONS into place and then cover them with canvas tarps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inductions dangerous, by drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, to set my brother Clarence and the king in deadly hate the one against the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare watches from backstage, getting more and more nervous by the audience's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the actor playing "Gloucester") A pox on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pox on Cecil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pox on Cecil! A pox on Cecil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actors are getting nervous.      People start throwin lettuce and tomatoes at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is Oxford's man with the Groundlings?

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare and Burbage exchange a worried glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELLS of St. James' Cathedral mark the hour as five o'clock. Essex looks to Southampton nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The play continues. "Gloucester" is plotting yet another death on his way to the throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hath she forgot already that brave prince,     Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since,     Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury? A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman- Fram'd in the prodigality of nature,     Young, valiant, wise, and no doubt right royal-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down with Cecil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actor playing "Gloucester" hesitates.     The audienc is getting unruly. FRANCESCO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up with Essex! To Essex House!     To Essex House!!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALLERIES
dialogues.text: Jonson is putting the pieces together.   He stands. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what Essex is waiting for-- (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is bringing him a mob. Jonson heads for the stairs. NASHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Oxford-- JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I don't know! But, the Tower-- Cecil, he already knows. He knows! (looks at Francesco)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-- I have to warn them! Nashe and Dekker are baffled as Jonson rushes down the stairs. VARIOUS GROUNDLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up with Essex! Essex! Death to Cecil!

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare turns to Burbage. SHAKESPEARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must close the play. Now!! BURBAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the...? Are you off your head? We can start to HEAR the audience chanting "Ess-ex,Ess- ex"...

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: It's getting unruly. "GLOUCESTER" (repeating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fram'd... in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and no doubt right royal- "Ess-ex, Ess-ex, Ess-ex"

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: Jonson pushes his way through the crowd, trying to head for Francesco. But they're separated by a sea of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Essex House! To Essex House! Death to Cecil! Traitor! A moment as the whole audience thinks on this. And then these chants are repeated by hundreds in the audience as they are pushing towards exits. And Jonson-- still struggling to reach Francesco-- is carried along with the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mob pours out of the doors. Storm clouds are gathering.   A RUMBLE of thunder sounds in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is waiting for his audience, looking out a window, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd pours through Bankside, growing in numbers as more people come out of taverns, whore-houses, etc... A shop-owner comes out of his store, confused.   Another MAN grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Essex!   And then to the Queen! (joins in the chanting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ess-ex! Ess-ex! The shop-owner begins to get the spirit of the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything, the crowd is twice the size it was moments ago. They head down the shop-lined bridge, full of bravado.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: is in the middle of the uncontrolled mob.   He spots Francesco nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mob has to slow down on the bridge. There is not much room. And then it happens! We are at the front of the mob, when the first soldiers appear and pull down the tarps revealing the cannons. People scream as an Officer appears and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire! And then the cannon FIRES. There is PANIC all around, and-

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: runs with the crowd, trying to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex and Southampton look tense.   They expected a mob here by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should be here by now... Essex frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go as we are! Now!! And he spurs his horse, and GALLOPS down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Queen! Southampton has no choice, and follows.   So do the 60 or so men behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford hears a cannon shot. But it could also be the sound of thunder. He goes to the window, sees the rain clouds, and dismisses the sound. A LADY IN WAITING enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord.    Her majesty will be with you shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138   Omitted

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mob is in panic.      And--

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: is in the middle of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor Jonson! We are betrayed!    Run! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson looks on in horror as Francesco is KILLED by a soldier wielding a pike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex and his men ROAR past the token guards at the front gate, and gallop into the--

dialogues.speaker: MAIN COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Essex rears his horse, looks around at the many windows that surround them from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Queen! To the Queen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His men repeat his plea.      And then, once again, anoth trap springs.

dialogues.speaker: THE GATE
dialogues.text: SLAMS closed.    And--

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS ARMED WITH MUSKETS
dialogues.text: line up in a colonnade in the story above.      Pole is i command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your aim!

dialogues.speaker: SOUTHAMPTON
dialogues.text: realizes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a trap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spread out! But before his men can obey--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COLONNADE
dialogues.text: Pole orders--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire!!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COURTYARD
dialogues.text: AND a hundred shots FIRE down into Essex and his men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford HEARS the SHOTS fired.    Confused, he goes to a window, looks out and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men fall all around Essex and Southampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pole walks down the colonnade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-load!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth heads for the window just as a door behind her SLAMS open, and Robert Cecil hurries in with a dozen guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty! You must away! Essex is in armed revolt! He's come to usurp you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex? I-- Edward is-- She seems like a confused old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must flee! Quickly! Majesty! He means to kill you and take your throne for himself! It takes only an instant for that to sink in. She looks enraged. And then she turns with a flurry, and heads back the way she came. The guards that were with Robert Cecil follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another fusillade is SHOT, and more of Essex's men go down. And then doors OPEN on the ground floor, and guards RUSH out to take down the survivors. Essex and Southampton valiantly fight, but there's just too many. They're soon surrounded... And Essex, knowing all is lost, raises his sword in defeat. Southampton sees this, and does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford watches all of this through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't forgive him this, Edward. Oxford turns, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex will be convicted and executed for treason. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As will your son. Oxford looks shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Didn't you think I knew? Of course I knew, Edward. My father told me all his secrets. All of them. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the most fascinating was not made known to me until after his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hated you, Edward, how he hated you. And yet he married his only daughter to you. I never knew why, until I read his last letter to me. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted his grandson to be an Earl. ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Edward.   He wanted his grandson to be a king. Oxford now looks confused. ROBERT CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth had several children, Edward, not just yours. She was sixteen for the first. Bloody Mary was still Queen, and our future Gloriana was out of favor. No one thought her very important at all. Except my father, of course. And when her first child was born, a male, my father took it, and hid it. The grandson of Henry VIII, the foundling of course had to be reared a nobleman. John De Vere, the previous Earl of Oxford, agreed to accept the task. Oxford goes ashen. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie... ROBERT CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I? (beat) Why do you think he worked so hard to become your guardian after your father died? He had it all planned years in advance. He would teach you everything he knew about statecraft, marry his daughter, and, after Elizabeth's death, proclaim you heir. His own grandchild to follow you on the throne. But he couldn't possibly predict what kind of failure you would become. How you would fail in politics, ignore your estates to the point of bankruptcy, all to write... (sneers) Poetry. (beat) Or that you would commit incest. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delicious isn't it? Right out of a Greek tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth would never have--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Slept with her son? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she ever knew, to tell you the truth. Though you never know with the Tudors. They all have had such strange tastes in bed-fellows. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have been a king, Edward. And your son after you. Except for the fact that... you were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining, hard. Oxford almost stumbles out of the building onto the now empty courtyard. The remains of the battle are still visible. Wounded, screaming horses struggle to stand... Oxford's a shell-- devoid of emotion. Broken. Hardly alive at all. He drops to his knees, the rain pouring down on him. We see the silhouette of a man watching through a window from the second story above. It's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Robert Cecil, a slight smile on his face. Pole approaches him from behind. Robert Cecil doesn't turn or acknowledge Pole, but speaks to him as he stares at Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a fair trial for Southampton... Evidence, witnesses, no false confessions. It must be above reproach. Though with a guilty verdict of course. Oh, and Pole-- (turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is any mention of that play-- (looks back at Oxford)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Make certain the secretaries refer to it as Richard the Second. There will be no mention of hunchbacks in the official record...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford is sitting in a chair, watching the river Thames, alone. Snow is falling and Oxford is covered in a thick blanket. He looks ill. Anne walks up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentence has been passed. Oxford looks over at her.   Anne smiles.   This news gives her great pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are to be be-headed. (with venom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them. Essex tomorrow, Southampton in a week. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son is going to be killed, Edward. By his own mother. Put that in one of your plays! And she leaves him with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essex-- dressed in black, but with a bright red waistcoat-- is led up a scaffold by guards, his hands bound behind him. Snow covers the courtyard. There are only a few witnesses, as befitting Essex's rank.

dialogues.speaker: ESSEX
dialogues.text: stands, looking at life one last time. The Executioner approaches with an axe. Essex turns, realizing it is time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike true. He kneels, resting his head on a wooden bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the Queen! And BAM!   Just as the axe lands we--

dialogues.speaker: FROM A WINDOW
dialogues.text: we see the body of Essex fall onto the scaffolding, his head into a basket. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southampton, a prisoner, is watching his future fate from a room high in a tower.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTS
dialogues.text: as they walk, limping along tiled floors.      We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors fly open and Oxford appears before Elizabeth, who is on her throne, regal and all in white, surrounded by courtiers, including Robert Cecil. But she looks very old, very ill. Everyone goes silent as Oxford approaches Elizabeth. Oxford makes no notice of them. He bows deeply in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us.    All of you. People start to exit.     But not Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us! Cecil exits, obviously worried.       When they are alone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look old... Oxford smiles sadly. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank your majesty for seeing me. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot have him. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is our son. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did commit High Treason! OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only wished for a place in government equal to their station. Equal to their birth. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You caused this! Your play, your words, caused my people to mob against me! Do you think I wasn't aware of your plot with this man Shakespeare, that I wouldn't recognize your voice? It should be your head on the block next week, not Southampton's! Oxford kneels. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take my head. In our son's stead. Elizabeth turns away from him, angered.   She walks to a window, turns her back on him. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither they nor I ever conspired against you. Cecil alone was our aim. He has corrupted your-- ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil?  He has kept me my throne! (beat) Mary, Queen of Scots... Philip, King of Spain... Four French Louis's... Eight Popes-- they all wanted my head. My throne. All of them! (beat) Yet here I remain... Because of the Cecils. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would have protected you-- ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would have protected me? You? My "loyal" Earls? (snarls) You think Essex and Southampton were the first to conspire against me, to try to take my throne? No! (beat) Only the Cecils could I trust! Commoners! They could never claim my throne. Never! Their wealth, their power, their survival, all depended on me. Me and no other! A long beat before-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let our child live... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) All Englishmen are my children! She has a coughing fit. Oxford patiently waits until she has recovered. Finally... ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he know? Oxford shakes his head. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I give him to you? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will never learn of it from me. She pauses for a long moment...    And then she decides. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must never know... Never. (beat) Take him. Oxford dares to smile, relieved. OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But only after my death! Only then! When all is complete. After James is crowned king, his crown safe, only then can you claim your son... our son. (beat) This Island will be whole. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Island, one kingdom, one King. (with disgust)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotsman though he be. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, that will be my final gift to my people. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I shall remain pure... Un-taken! Elizabeth again looks out a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treason... that is all that has come from you... your son... Your plays... None will be claimed by you. None. And she leaves the throne chamber. Oxford looks after her as the SOUNDS of BELLS slowly begin GONGING as we-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell-ringing comes from St. Paul's Cathedral, the largest church in the City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the frozen river Thames we see the funeral procession for the greatest Queen England has ever seen. Everybody follows the carriage with the casket of the queen. All the lords and ladies of the land.   All wear elaborate black clothing. First is Robert Cecil.   Proudly.   Not far walks Oxford. He is a statue. Devoid of emotion. And then joyous CHORAL MUSIC replaces the CHURCH GONGS as we--

dialogues.speaker: A GOLD CROWN
dialogues.text: as it is placed on a head.    We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES I (late 30's) is being crowned by the Archbishop. All the lords and ladies of the land are standing in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT CECIL
dialogues.text: is watching James. His face betrays his proud feelings. All of Robert Cecil's desires have come true. Oxford's wife Anne is there, but Oxford is nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's foggy. Oxford stands next to a carriage, waiting as the gates open, and Southampton-- scruffy and a bit worse for wear-- is escorted out. Southampton smiles weakly when he sees Oxford waiting for him. The two men walk towards each other and embrace. Both men have tears in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare is on stage, supervising a rehearsal of "Much Ado About Nothing". He doesn't look pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line won't get a laugh that way. You must accent the word sirrah--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will!   Will Shakespeare! Shakespeare turns and sees Jonson heading his way. Jonson is completely drunk, waving a sword in one hand, a tankard in another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So!    Off to the palace are you? Shakespeare immediately sees Jonson's condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A command performance for our new king! Even in bloody Scotland they've heard of bloody Will Shakespeare, have they? Fraud. Charlatan. Counterfeiter of wit! Murderer! The actors on stage are all watching, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, please... But Jonson CHARGES Shakespeare. Shakespeare easily dodges the drunk Jonson. Jonson ROARS and attacks again. Shakespeare dodges again, turns, and manages to grab Jonson by the throat. They are face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came to me, Ben. You came to me! They stare at each other and then Shakespeare SHOVES him off. Jonson falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson-- only semi conscious-- is carried by the actors and dumped into the street. They leave him there. He wallows in the mud for a beat. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Jonson? Jonson looks up to see one of Oxford's servants standing above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The servant guides Jonson towards Oxford's bedroom just as Anne and a DOCTOR emerge from it. She recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to servant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this man doing in my house? The servant doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jonson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will leave at once. My husband is quite ill--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was your husband who sent for me, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am dismissing you-- A SECOND DOCTOR exits the sick man's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Jonson? Jonson nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford, in bed, looks quite ill, sweat covering his brow. He furiously writes on a small tablet on his lap. He holds up his hand for silence as Jonson enters, the doctor following behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, doctor. The doctor exits. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here, Jonson... He points to a chair by the bed. When Jonson sits down he notices a big pile of manuscripts by the side of the bed. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know, Jonson, that my family can trace its peerage farther back than any family in the kingdom?   We fought at Crecy. At Bosworth Field. At Agincourt. (beat) I inherited my Earldom as one of the wealthiest men ever to breathe English air... and at last breath, I shall be one of the poorest. Jonson looks on sadly. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never a voice in government. Never a sword raised in glorious battle. No immortal deeds for my heirs to know me by. (beat) Words, merely words, are to be my legacy... (beat) You alone watch my plays and know them as mine. When I hear the applause, the cheering, of the audience, all those hands clapping, they are celebrating... another man. But in that cacophony of sounds, I strained to hear the sound of two hands only. Yours. (beat) But heard them, I never did. Jonson stares at him. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death takes away all pretense and demands honesty from its target. You, you have never told me... never told me what you thought of my work... To answer is not an easy task for Jonson's ego.    He hesitates. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) I find... your words... the most wondrous ever heard on our stage.    On any stage... Ever. The two men now looking each other in the eye. JONSON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) You are the soul of the age... Oxford smiles at the thought of it.   Then-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me... promise me, Jonson, that you will keep our secret safe. That you won't expose Shakespeare... JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord? OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen it in your face... He vexes you. How could he not? But he is not your burden. He is mine. Then he nods to the manuscripts by his side. OXFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my writings. The plays, the sonnets... Keep them safe. Keep them from my family. From the Cecil's. Wait a few years, and then, publish them. Jonson looks stricken. JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not worthy of this charge, my lord. I... I betrayed you... I told them of your-- OXFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have made it my life to know the character of men, Jonson. I know you. You may have betrayed me, but you will never betray my words... He puts the last manuscript on the pile. Jonson looks at the--

dialogues.speaker: FRONT PAGE
dialogues.text: Which reads "DEDICATION", then more words, starting with: "To the Earl of Southampton"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson leaves Oxford's room, visibly shaken.    The manuscripts are under his arm. Anne, Oxford's wife is still there, surround by doctors. Then she sees Jonson leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out! You, your friends, your blasphemous theaters, have brought nothing but ruin and dishonor to this family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruin? Dishonor? Madam. You, your family, me, even Elizabeth herself shall be remembered solely because we had the honor to live whilst your husband put ink to paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson exits the building and walks away. He reads the dedication on the first page of the manuscript as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Earl of Southampton. The love I dedicate to your lordship is without end; whereof this pamphlet, without beginning, is but a superfluous moiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson freezes, and looks back at Oxford's house, realizing there is another whole layer to all this; exactly what he can only guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few hours later. Oxford has died in his bed. Anne watches as a doctor covers his face with a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I have done is yours; what I have to do is yours; being part in all I have, devoted, yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A casket is being interred into the family mausoleum. Anne is there, as are Oxford's children. So is Robert Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were my worth greater, my duty would show greater; meantime, as it is, it is bound to your lordship, to whom I wish long life... still lengthened with all happiness. Southampton is there as well.   Watching. Tears roll down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we began. A bucket of water is DUMPED on Jonson. He regains consciousness and looks around. Somewhat confused he sees: Robert Cecil limping out of the dark towards him. Robert Cecil leans down, and very close to his ear, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make all this go away, Jonson... To be but a dream. Like one of your plays... Or, I can bring you so much pain-- pain that were you given a thousand years, and a thousand quills, you could never justly describe... Cecil steps back. CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have them. All his manuscripts. My sister saw you leave Oxford Stone with them under your arm. Jonson takes a long time before answering. Will he betray Oxford? JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were destroyed...   burned...   by your own men... Cecil doesn't know whether to believe him or not. INTERROGATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying... JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord? Why would I lie? Is there a man alive who has reason to hate him more than I? Jonson stares directly at Cecil, knowing he is speaking about Cecil as well as himself. JONSON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was something I could never be. An undeniable perfection... that plagued my soul... And to him I was... nothing. A messenger. Nothing more. Cecil stares into his eyes for a long moment, searching for the truth. Then he smiles. CECIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go!   He tells the truth. Robert Cecil turns to leave, but then turns a last time. CECIL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jonson-- better him, won't you? Wipe his memory for all time. For you. And for me. Robert Cecil smiles at Jonson, who can only stare at him. Finally: JONSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) I am afraid that this is not possible, my lord. Robert Cecil's smile freezes and he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson is getting released. He walks away....a lonely figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide from above...Still smoking from the fire....All the sudden we make out Jonson searching through the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set for a Court performance of a play. Courtiers bow as King James I enters the chamber, Robert Cecil two steps behind him. James takes his seat right in front of the stage, as Elizabeth used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonson's eyes search the ground.   And, eventually, he finds it--

dialogues.speaker: THE METAL BOX
dialogues.text: that seems to somehow have survived the conflagration.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: opens the box.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BOX
dialogues.text: Are the manuscripts Oxford gave him. Jonson smiles, relieved. They are singed at the edges, but they are there. We hear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-- for a muse of fire... that would ascend the brightest heaven of invention...

dialogues.speaker: AN ACTOR
dialogues.text: playing Prologue. He is the same actor who introduced the "play" at the beginning of the film. But now he wears Elizabethan clothing-- but again, all monochromatic and grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, and monarchs to behold the swelling scene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is standing on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us, ciphers to this great accompt, on your imaginary forces work. King James' watches enthusiastically, Robert Cecil right next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had seen some of this Shakespeare's plays in Edinburgh, Sir Robert. I must tell you, we enjoyed them immensely, and look forward to seeing many more, now that we are in London... I presume you are as avid a theater man as myself? Robert Cecil's smile remains frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, your majesty... The CAMERA moves away from them and we realize we are on the theater stage where we started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Prologue" turns and addresses his audience (and us) in the modern theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cecil remained the most powerful man in the Court of King James, though he could not prevent the public theaters from becoming ever more popular. William Shakespeare, however, spent the remaining years of his life not in the playhouses of London, but in the small town of his birth, Stratford upon Avon, as a businessman and grain merchant. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROLOGUE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Jonson succeeded in his desire to be the most celebrated playwright of his time, becoming England's first Poet Laureate. And in 1623, he wrote the dedication to the collected works of the man we call William Shakespeare. (beat) And so... though our story is finished, our poet's is not. For his monument is ever-living, made not of stone but of verse, and it shall be remembered... as long as words are made of breath and breath of life. The curtains close. END CREDITS start to roll...
